questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with shortness of breath and cough. She reports her symptoms started after she began working in a coal mine several months ago, and they have increased in severity. She also reports diffuse arthralgias in her hands which is worse in the morning and improves after about two-hours of working. Temperature 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 138/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination is notable for diffuse pulmonary rales as well as the finding depicted below:  


Reproduced from: wikipedia    

Laboratory studies reveal rheumatoid factor is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This coal miner presents with findings of interstitial lung disease and rheumatoid arthritis (ulnar deviation depicted above) consistent with Caplan syndrome, a type of pneumoconiosis.  

Caplan syndrome refers to a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis that manifests with intrapulmonary nodules on chest x-ray. Patients with this disorder will have typical features of rheumatoid arthritis including painful joints and morning stiffness, as well as tender, swollen metacarpophalangeal joints and rheumatoid nodules. In addition, patients will have a history of exposure to inorganic particulate matter such as asbestos, silicosis, or coal dust and subsequent decline in pulmonary function.    

Rheumatoid arthritis alters how the immune system responds to these foreign particles, resulting in accelerated development of multiple peripheral basilar nodules and lung fibrosis. There is immune hyperactivity that is initiated by silica exposure in which monocytes and macrophages release cytokines such as interleukin-1 and tumor necrosis factor alpha. Lymphocytes are subsequently activated by the cytokines released by macrophages, leading to an autoimmune phenomenon in genetically predisposed individuals who have RA. Ultimately, this leads to the development of impaired diffusion interface for gas exchange, decreased lung compliance, and a restrictive lung disease pattern.  

Option Analysis

✅ Caplan syndrome :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emphysema :
Incorrect: Emphysema describes permanent alveoli enlargement and loss of alveolar wall elasticity. It is most commonly caused by an irritant, such as tobacco smoke, which triggers inflammation in the alveoli. Inflammatory cells (e.g. neutrophils) gather in the lungs and release destructive proteases, which degrade connective tissue in the alveolar walls.  
❌ Asthma :
Incorrect: Asthma is an obstructive lung disease that presents with wheezing in response to inhaled particulate matter. This patient has evidence of rales, which is instead concerning for an interstitial pulmonary inflammatory process.  
❌ Anthracosis :
Incorrect: Anthracosis is an asymptomatic condition found in many urban dwellers exposed to sooty air. It is characterized by small areas of blackened lung tissue, reflective of inhaled carbon.   
❌ Sarcoidosis :
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis can present with findings consistent with interstitial lung disease and polyarthropathy; however, it is usually associated with additional clinical features such as lymphadenopathy, uveitis, or Bell's palsy. Additionally, sarcoidosis is not classically associated with a positive rheumatoid factor.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with a dry cough and shortness of breath. He reports worsening symptoms for months and states he is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. He usually drinks two beers everyday after he finishes his work as a sandblaster for the city government. Vitals are within normal limits. His physical examination is unremarkable. He undergoes spirometry which demonstrates an increased FEV1/FVC ratio. Which of the following radiographic features is most likely to be observed based on this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Nodular opacities and hilar lymph node calcification of the upper lobes
Small, rounded nodular opacities of the upper lobes
Reticular bilateral opacities of the lower lobes
Small bilateral opacities throughout both lungs sparring the apices and the bases
Honeycombing pattern of the upper lobes

questions.solution:
This patient who works as a sandblaster presents with worsening shortness of breath and a dry cough, concerning silicosis. Of the choices listed, nodular opacities and hilar lymph node calcification of the upper lobes (also referred to as egg shell calcification) is most commonly associated with silicosis.  

Clues to the etiology of a restrictive lung disease can often be elicited from the anatomic location of disease on chest radiographic or chest CT. Diseases that tend to affect the upper lobes of the lung include: sarcoidosis (late), silicosis, berylliosis, and coal workers pneumoconiosis.   

Diseases that tend to affect the lower lobes include asbestosis and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Diseases that tend to have a diffuse or non-specific pattern include sarcoidosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and medication toxicities.    



Option Analysis

✅ Nodular opacities and hilar lymph node calcification of the upper lobes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Small, rounded nodular opacities of the upper lobes :
Incorrect: Coal workers pneumoconiosis manifests with nodular opacities of the upper lobes and is most commonly asymptomatic. Patients at risk for this disease include those who work in coal mines. 
❌ Reticular bilateral opacities of the lower lobes :
Incorrect: Asbestosis predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung and is more prominent in those who work in shipbuilding, roofing, plumbing, and manufacturing.  
❌ Small bilateral opacities throughout both lungs sparring the apices and the bases:
Incorrect: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis results in a diffuse reticular pattern that does not predominantly affect the upper or lower lobes. Clinically, patients with this disease have repeated exposure to an offending antigen—such as bird breeders. 
❌ Honeycombing pattern of the upper lobes :
Incorrect: Late stage sarcoidosis tends to present with a honeycombing pattern affecting the upper lobes of the lung. This patient has no other associated clinical features of sarcoidosis (e.g. erythema nodosum).

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man comes to the office for follow up regarding pulmonary function testing for ongoing  shortness of breath. The pulmonary function testing was notable for decreased total lung capacity, an increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volume. He subsequently undergoes a lung biopsy that demonstrates the following histologic image:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia    

Which of the following diseases is implicated in the above microscopic lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient’s pulmonary function testing is notable for decreased total lung capacity, an increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volume, consistent with restrictive lung disease. The lung biopsy demonstrates alveolar septae thickening with the presence of non-caseating granulomas (as indicated by the yellow arrows). Of the diagnoses listed, only hypersensitivity pneumonitis is associated with non-caseating granulomas.  

Restrictive lung diseases implicated in granulomatous lung disease include sarcoidosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and berylliosis. Regardless, the development of granulomas in these diseases is similar and mediated via a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. In this process, antigen presenting cells like macrophages present antigens to CD4+ T-cells and secrete IL-12. Secretion of IL-12 by the macrophage induces differentiation of these CD4 cells into type 1 helper cells (Th1), which migrate to sites of antigen deposition where they release interferon-gamma, activating additional macrophages. As more macrophages become activated, they recruit even more macrophages and neutrophils through release of TNF-alpha. These cells surround the antigen and differentiated into epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated Langhans giant cells, ultimately forming granulomas.

In these diseases, the granulomas are considered non-caseating due to the absence of central necrosis. This finding is in contrast to caseating granulomatous diseases such as tuberculosis, where the center of the granuloma becomes necrotic. Over time, the continued immunological reactions cause scarring and fibrosis, resulting in a pattern of restrictive lung disease.    

Option Analysis

✅ Hypersensitivity pneumonitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease :
Incorrect: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is a type of obstructive lung disease that presents with increased total lung capacity, decreased FEV1/FVC, and increased residual volume. It is not associated with granulomatous formation. 
❌ Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis :
Incorrect: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a type of restrictive lung disease that will typically demonstrate decreased total lung capacity, an increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volume; however, it is not associated with granulomatous formation.
❌ Amiodarone toxicity :
Incorrect: Amiodarone toxicity can result in pulmonary fibrosis and restrictive lung disease that will typically demonstrate decreased total lung capacity, an increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volume; however, it is not associated with granulomatous formation.
❌ Asthma :
Incorrect: Asthma is a type of obstructive lung disease that presents with increased total lung capacity, decreased FEV1/FVC, and increased residual volume. Histologically, it is characterized by  Curschmann spirals and Charcot-Leyden crystals.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with retrosternal chest pain. ECG reveals ST-segment elevations in leads I and aVL suggestive of anterolateral myocardial infarction. Enroute to the cardiac catheterization lab, he undergoes ventricular fibrillation arrest and cannot be resuscitated. His post-mortem analysis demonstrates fibrotic nodules in the upper lobes of the lung, and a pathological specimen is shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia  

Review of his past medical history demonstrates hypertension, diabetes, as well as a 5-pack-year smoking history and work as a sandblaster. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of his lung findings on post-mortem analysis?

choices.text: Alveolar insult and formation of hyaline membranes
Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucous secreting glands in bronchi
Neutrophil-mediated destruction of connective tissue in the alveolar walls

questions.solution:
This patient demonstrates fibrotic nodules in the upper lobes of the lung and has a history of working as a sandblaster -- findings consistent with silicosis, a type of pneumoconiosis. This spectrum of diseases is largely due to the impaired ability of alveolar macrophages to ingest and properly dispose of inhaled particulate matter. On pathological examination, silicotic nodules demonstrate concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers surrounding an amorphous center. This “whorled” appearance of collagen fibers is characteristic of silicosis.  

Pneumoconiosis refers to a set of restrictive lung diseases and interstitial fibrosis induced by types of inhaled inorganic particulate matter. The major types of pneumoconiosis are asbestosis, silicosis, and coal workers pneumoconiosis. Berylliosis is often classified as a pneumoconiosis as well; however, its pathogenesis is mediated by a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.    

Regardless of the type, the pathogenesis of disease is similar. Inhaled particulate matter becomes impacted at distal airway bifurcations, where alveolar macrophages attempt to phagocytose and digest the foreign material. More often than not, the alveolar macrophage is unable to effectively clear the foreign material, triggering an immune response. Secretion of inflammatory cytokines and growth factors results in collagen deposition by fibroblasts, scar tissue formation, and interstitial hardening. Over time, this process manifests with an impaired diffusion interface for gas exchange, decreased lung compliance, and a restrictive lung disease pattern.    

Option Analysis

✅ Failure to phagocytose inhaled particles :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Alveolar insult and formation of hyaline membranes :
Incorrect: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) results in the development of hyaline membranes and diffuse interstitial edema. Autopsy specimens demonstrate diffuse alveolar damage.
❌ Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucous secreting glands in bronchi :
Incorrect: Chronic bronchitis results from long-standing smoking and causes hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucous secreting glands. It does not induce formation of fibrotic nodules in the upper lung lobes. 
❌ Neutrophil-mediated destruction of connective tissue in the alveolar walls  :
Incorrect: Emphysema describes permanent alveoli enlargement and loss of alveolar wall elasticity. It is most commonly caused by an irritant, such as tobacco smoke, which triggers inflammation in the alveoli. Inflammatory cells (e.g. neutrophils) gather in the lungs and release destructive proteases, which degrade connective tissue in the alveolar walls. This patient’s smoking history is relatively short, and the pathological specimen showing nodular collagenous fibrosis is suggestive of another etiology. 
❌ Proliferation of undifferentiated neuroendocrine cells :
Incorrect: Small cell carcinoma of the lung results in an amorphous mass usually arising from central bronchi. This patient’s upper lung nodules and pathological specimen showing nodular collagenous fibrosis with anthracotic pigment and a peripheral rim of lymphocytes is suggestive of another etiology.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to his family physician for a routine checkup. Upon walking the short distance from the waiting room to the exam room, the patient becomes short of breath. He states that he frequently feels tired throughout the day and has had these symptoms for years. His previous physician performed a full cardiac workup, which was unremarkable. Temperature is 99.0°F, blood pressure is 150/110 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The patient has a BMI of 42 kg/m2. The patient undergoes in-laboratory polysomnography testing, which demonstrates hypoventilation during sleep. Further laboratory testing demonstrates an elevated serum bicarbonate level. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Inflammation and obstruction of distal airways

questions.solution:
This patient with morbid obesity is suffering from obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS). This restrictive lung disease occurs secondary to increased mass of the abdomen and thoracic cavity, preventing the chest wall from adequately expanding with respiration. Due to these altered respiratory mechanics, patients with OHS have reduced ventilation--primarily in the lower lobes of the lung. This restriction causes a mismatching in the ventilation-perfusion ratio, triggering hypoxemia. In addition, total lung capacity, expiratory reserve volume, and residual functional capacity are reduced in patients with OHS.

OHS is a diagnosis of exclusion, as patients often suffer also with concomitant obstructive sleep apnea and, to a lesser extent, central sleep apnea. The distinguishing feature of OHS includes the presence of hypercapnic symptoms during the daytime, as evidenced in this patient by his increased serum bicarbonate levels--suggestive of chronic hypercapnia. Polysomnography may also help distinguish between OHS and obstructive sleep apnea. Importantly, excluding other cardiac and pulmonary disorders such including COPD or congestive heart failure is critical. First line therapy includes positive airway pressure therapy, bilevel positive airway pressure, and weight reduction. Second line measures include  pharmacologic adjuncts such as medroxyprogesterone or acetazolamide or surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obstruction of the oropharynx:
Incorrect: This answer describes obstructive sleep apnea, which presents with episodes of apnea during sleep in addition to hypoventilation.
❌ Desensitization of chemoreceptors :
Incorrect: This answer describes central sleep apnea, which is characterized by irregular patterns of apnea and hyperventilation caused by desensitization to PCO2 chemoreceptors.
❌ Inflammation and obstruction of distal airways:
Incorrect: This answer describes asthma, which is unlikely in this patient given his age and other associated findings on exam and polysomnography.
❌ Increased pulmonary artery pressure:
Incorrect: Pulmonary hypertension can occur secondary to sleep apnea and obesity hypoventilation syndrome; however, it is a late manifestation of the disease and is not the primary pathophysiologic driver.
✅ Imparied lung expansion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with shortness of breath. She reports worsening shortness of breath and fatigue over the past several months and states, “I just don’t feel like myself.” Her past medical history includes obesity and hypertension. She smokes one half-pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 120/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination reveals coarse bilateral breath sounds and red tender lumps on the anterior shins. A chest x-ray is performed and shown below.  


Reproduced from: Radiopedia    

Which of the following is most likely to be seen on pulmonary function testing for this patient?

choices.text: Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↓  ↑  ↓  ↓  ↑

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient) ↑   ↓  ↑  normalnormal

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↓  ↑  ↓  normal normal

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↑ normal  ↑ ↓  normal

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient) ↑   ↑  ↑   ↓  ↑

questions.solution:
This patient presents with shortness of breath, fatigue, erythema nodosum (red tender nodules on the shins), and a chest x-xray demonstrating hilar lymphadenopathy, consistent with sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a type of restrictive lung disease, of the diffuse parenchymal lung disease subtype. These patients present with usual parameters of restrictive lung disease (decreased TLC, increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased RV) in addition to a decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) and increased arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient).  

Diffuse parenchymal lung disease (DPLD) refers to a subtype of restrictive lung diseases characterized by fibrotic, rigid lungs with decreased compliance and increased elasticity. The causes of DPLD are numerous and include sarcoidosis, pneumoconiosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, vasculitis such as Goodpasture syndrome and granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and drug toxicities (e.g. amiodarone). Regardless of the etiology, scarring and fibrosis of lung parenchyma results in stiff lungs that cannot adequately fill during inhalation. On pulmonary function testing, this restriction manifests with decreased TLC, decreased RV, and a decreased FEV1. Due to increased elasticity of lung tissue in this disease state, the FEV1 or volume of air exhaled over one second, increases in proportion to the forced vital capacity.  

The distinguishing feature of DPLD from other forms of restrictive lung disease is a decreased DLCO and increased A-a gradient. The DLCO refers to how easily gases are transferred between the alveoli and the bloodstream using carbon monoxide as a surrogate marker. Fibrosis at the alveolar-capillary level impairs gas transfer and increases the A-a gradient, or difference between the amount of oxygen in the alveoli and the bloodstream.  

During respiration, affected portions of the lung receive less oxygen, resulting in reflexive pulmonary vasoconstriction to shunt blood towards more adequately ventilated areas of the lung. Over time, this shunting results in pulmonary hypertension, right ventricular hypertrophy, and subsequent right heart failure or cor pulmonale.   

Option Analysis

✅   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↓  ↑  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient) ↑   ↓  ↑  normalnormal :
Incorrect: Obstructive lung diseases, not restrictive lung diseases, present with these parameters. While this patient does smoke, the chest x-ray does not demonstrate findings consistent with the diagnosis of COPD, such as flattened diaphragms or hyperinflated lungs. 
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↓  ↑  ↓  normal normal:
Incorrect: Restrictive lung diseases due to poor breathing mechanics (e.g., scoliosis, obesity hypoventilation) will demonstrate similar spirometry findings; however, they will have a normal DLCO and A-a gradient because these diseases do not have structural abnormalities at the alveolar-capillary interface impairing gas exchange. 
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↑ normal  ↑ ↓  normal :
Incorrect:  These findings are not indicative of obstructive or restrictive lung disease.
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient) ↑   ↑  ↑   ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: An increased FEV1/FVC in the setting of increased TLC and RV is rarely found and is more commonly due to measurement error.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with shortness of breath. He reports worsening shortness of breath ever since he started working as a foundry-man where he is frequently outside using a stone cutter. He has no symptoms of arthralgias, fatigue, or malaise. His past medical history is notable for obesity and hypertension. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is non-contributory. A chest x-ray is performed which shows innumerable, small, rounded opacities in the upper lung zones and is demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia    

Laboratory studies show negative rheumatoid factor antibodies and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibodies. If left untreated, this patient is at increased risk for which of the following disease processes?
questions.solution:
This patient, who works in a foundry, presents with increasing dyspnea on exertion. His chest x-ray demonstrates nodular opacities of the upper lobes, consistent with silicosis. This pneumoconiosis is known to increase the risk of pulmonary tuberculosis by three fold, due to silica’s ability to disrupt phagolysosome formation. Mycobacterial infection, particularly tuberculosis, is a well-established complication of silicosis and should be suspected when a patient with silicosis develops constitutional symptoms, worsening respiratory impairment, hemoptysis, or changes in the chest radiograph.  

Silicosis refers to a fibrotic pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of fine particles of crystalline silicon dioxide. Patients at increased susceptibility to inhalation of these particles include those who work in foundries, sandblasting, and silica mines. Development of silicosis occurs when these crystalline particles become lodged in small airways. Alveolar macrophages attempt to remove the particles and initiate a cascade of inflammation resulting in collagen deposition and fibrosis surrounding the silicate particles, forming silicotic nodules. As these nodules mature, the center becomes a dense fibrotic scar, giving rise to an “onion skin” appearance. Unless exposure is terminated, these nodules eventually merge, resulting in diffuse lung fibrosis.   

Clinically, silicosis manifests most commonly with dyspnea or a non-productive cough. As fibrosis progresses, more severe complications may occur including hypoxia, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale. Diagnosis of silicosis rests on history, physiologic, radiographic, and histologic findings. Patients will often have restrictive physiology on pulmonary function testing, as well as nodular opacities and hilar lymph node calcification of the upper lobes. Lung biopsy will typically demonstrate birefringent particles of silica surrounded by fibrosis. Treatment of silicosis involves removal from the exposure and supportive care.  



Option Analysis

✅ Pulmonary tuberculosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mesothelioma :
Incorrect: Asbestos exposure is associated with the development of mesothelioma—a malignancy of the arising from the pleura. Patients with exposure to asbestos typically have a history of working in shipbuilding, plumbing, roofing, or the textile industry. Silicosis is not associated with this malignancy.
❌ Caplan syndrome:
Incorrect: Caplan syndrome refers to a combination of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and pneumoconiosis. RA alters how the immune system responds to foreign particles (such as silica) and results in the rapid development of multiple peripheral basilar nodules and lung fibrosis. This patient does not have any signs or symptoms of RA, and his negative antibody studies make this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Acute respiratory distress syndrome :
Incorrect: Acute respiratory distress syndrome or ARDS typically results after an acute pulmonary insult such as acute pneumonia, near drowning, or a massive pulmonary embolism. It does not typically occur after chronic lung fibrosis. 
❌ Superior sulcus tumor:
Incorrect: A superior sulcus tumor, also known as a Pancoast tumor, is not typically associated with chronic silicosis. This type of tumor can manifest with Horner syndrome, hoarseness, or brachial plexus injury.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with increasing lower back pain. He reports his pain is worse in the morning and improves with exercise. His other past medical history is notable for ulcerative colitis. He undergoes testing for HLA-B27, and his results are positive. On follow up several years later, the patient reports worsening shortness of breath with exertion. Which of the following pulmonary parameters is most likely to be normal in this patient?
questions.solution:
This male patient presents with low back pain, worse with exertion, and on follow up several years later, he has increasing shortness of breath. This overall clinical presentation is consistent with ankylosing spondylitis, which can cause restrictive lung disease due to altered breathing mechanics. Of the pulmonary parameters listed, only the A-a gradient can determine if his shortness of breath is from a pulmonary etiology or an extrapulmonary etiology; in the setting of ankylosing spondylitis, it is most likely to be normal.  

Extrapulmonary restrictive lung disease refers to diseases that interfere with the structural mechanics of breathing. In these disease states, the A-a gradient and diffusing capacity gases is normal, because the lung tissue itself is not damaged. Extrapulmonary restrictive lung diseases due to weakness of respiratory muscles include polio, myasthenia gravis, or Guillain-Barré syndrome. Diseases resulting in restrictive lung disease due to structural abnormalities include scoliosis, morbid obesity, and ankylosing spondylitis.    

Option Analysis

✅ A-a gradient :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Functional residual capacity:
Incorrect: Functional residual capacity refers to the volume of air in the lungs after normal expiration. It is overall decreased in restrictive lung diseases such as ankylosing spondylitis. 
❌ FEV1/FVC:
Incorrect: The FEV1/FVC ratio is typically increased in restrictive lung diseases; however, it cannot be used to differentiate between intrapulmonary and extrapulmonary disease. 
❌ Total lung capacity:
Incorrect: Total lung capacity refers to the volume of air in the lungs at maximal inspiration. It is overall decreased in restrictive lung diseases. 
❌  Forced vital capacity:
Incorrect: Forced vital capacity refers to the amount of air that can be forcibly exhaled from your lungs after taking the deepest breath possible.  It is overall decreased in restrictive lung diseases.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with a worsening cough and shortness of breath for the past 5 months. He reports he used to be able to walk four blocks before becoming short of breath but now can only walk a half-a-block. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He smokes 5-10 cigarettes per day and does not use alcohol or illicit substances. He has worked as a bird breeder for over 15 years. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 17/min, blood pressure is 138/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination is notable for a thin, cachectic male with coarse breath sounds bilaterally and digital clubbing. Chest CT scan is demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia    
Lung biopsy is performed and reveals aggregates of epithelioid macrophages with multinucleated giant cells. This patient is most likely to demonstrate which of the following respiratory parameters?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of working as a bird breeder, presents with worsening dyspnea on exertion, malaise, and has a CT scan of the chest demonstrating diffuse ground glass opacities. His history and clinical findings are consistent with chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis, a restrictive lung disease.  

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a granulomatous disorder in which the lungs become inflamed in response to inhaled microorganisms, plant and animal proteins, or chemicals. The disease was colloquially referred to as bird fancier disease, as antigens in pigeon or bird droppings were the common offending agent. It is divided into an acute and chronic form. Acute disease often presents with fevers, cough, and shortness of breath within hours of exposure to the antigen and then subsequent resolution of symptoms after removal of the exposure. Chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis presents similarly, but with a more insidious onset over years of exposure. These patients often have sustained shortness of breath, weight loss, a pattern of restrictive lung disease, and, in its worse case, respiratory failure.    

Diagnosis of the disease rests on compatible clinical, radiographic, physiologic, and histopathologic findings. Radiographic findings include diffuse bilateral ground glass opacities on CT-scan as well as numerous, poorly defined small opacities throughout both lungs—sparring the apices and the bases. Spirometry will demonstrate a restrictive lung physiology, characterized by decreased FEV1/FVC ratio and bronchiolar lavage samples will often have increased lymphocytes and mast cells. Lung biopsy will typically demonstrate noncaseating granulomas (aggregates of epithelioid macrophages with multinucleated giant cells) as well.  

One of the key tests performed is called an inhalation challenge, where the patient physically inhales the suspected antigen and is monitored for developing symptoms. If diagnosed early, the disease process can be reversed. Most cases are treated by simply instructing the patient to avoid the exposure, while more severe cases require treatment with steroids.  





Option Analysis

✅ Increased FEV1/FVC:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased FEV1/FVC:
Incorrect: Obstructive lung diseases such as emphysema or asthma will demonstrate an decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. While this patient does smoke, the chest CT-findings are inconsistent with emphysematous changes, which would instead demonstrate hyperinflation and hyperlucency of the lung fields. Pulmonary examination would also demonstrate reduced breath sounds. 
❌ Decreased A-a gradient :
Incorrect: Restrictive lung diseases like hypersensitivity pneumonitis tend to present with an increased A-a gradient due to the impaired diffusion of gases across the inflamed and fibrosed alveolar-capillary membrane. 
❌ Increased residual volume:
Incorrect: Increased residual volume are findings consistent with obstructive lung disease such as emphysema. This patient’s CT findings do not have evidence of hyperinflated lung fields. 
❌ Normal diffusing capacity for CO:
Incorrect: A normal diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide may be seen in restrictive lung diseases where there is no parenchymal damage, such as scoliosis or morbid obesity. However, in the case of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, inflammation and damage to the alveolar capillary interface results in impaired diffusing capacity for CO.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with progressive shortness of breath over the past year. He reports he is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. He works as an accountant and smokes two to three cigarettes on the weekend. The patient is lost to follow-up, and several years later, the patient requires a bilateral lung transplantation. Pathologic evaluation of the patient’s lungs reveals a honeycomb pattern with fibrotic walls most prominent in the subpleural and perilobular regions. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Recurrent episodes of lung injury and disordered healing

questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive dyspnea and undergoes bilateral lung transplantation with his native lungs demonstrating a honeycomb pattern with fibrotic walls most prominent in the subpleural and perilobular regions. In the absence of other known causes, this patient's presentation is most consistent with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis—a disease of unknown etiology thought to be due to repeated cycles of lung injury and wound healing with increased collagen deposition.  

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease of unknown etiology. It is identified in patients as a diagnosis of exclusion—once other types of restrictive lung diseases are ruled out. The known risk factors for disease include male gender, smoking, and old age. While the precise precipitant of disease is unknown, lung injury results in destruction of type I pneumocytes and subsequent overproliferation of type II pneumocytes and myofibroblasts that do not undergo apoptosis. Increased collagen deposition by these cells leads to stiffening of the lungs, resulting in traction bronchiectasis, where fibrosis pulls apart the parenchyma, resulting in irreversible dilation of the bronchi and bronchioles.  

Patients with this disease are usually asymptomatic in the early stages, but as the disease progresses, patients typically develop a dry cough or shortness of breath. At later stages, patients may develop cyanosis, digital clubbing, or respiratory failure. The disease is diagnosed by first excluding other causes of pulmonary fibrosis, spirometry, and radiography. Pulmonary function testing will typically reveal a restrictive pattern, and chest CT will demonstrate a honeycomb pattern. Treatment involves supplemental oxygen, the antifibrotic medication pirfenidone (inhibits transforming growth factor beta), and lung transplantation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Recurrent episodes of lung injury and disordered healing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deficiency of a proteinase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is instead associated with emphysematous changes in the lung tissue and obstructive lung disease. 
❌ Proliferation of undifferentiated neuroendocrine cells :
Incorrect: Small cell carcinoma of the lung results in an amorphous mass usually arising from central bronchi. 
❌ Mixed type III/IV hypersensitivity reaction :
Incorrect: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis results in diffuse reticulonodular fibrosis due to a mixed type III/IV hypersensitivity reaction. Patients will typically have a history of repeated exposure to an offending antigen, history of working on a farm, or history as a bird breeder. 
❌ Multisystem granulomatous disorder:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis results in a granuloma formation in the lungs with hilar adenopathy. This patient lacks other history associated with this disease process including uveitis, Bell's palsy, or arthritis.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old African American woman presents to her primary care physician with burning and redness of her left eye. She reports onset of symptoms approximately one week ago, but on review of systems, she also reports chronic fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. She has no significant past medical history, but she states her mother has an “autoimmune” disorder; she is unsure of the details. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs and has not traveled recently. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 130/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air.  Physical examination reveals red, hard, painful lumps over the anterior shins. Ocular examination of the left eye is depicted below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia    

This patient’s clinical presentation is most likely associated with which of the following pathological features?
questions.solution:
This young, African-American female presents with constitutional symptoms including weight loss, fatigue, shortness of breath and cough. Additional findings include erythema nodosum (tender nodules over the shins) and an image depicting uveitis, or inflammation of the uvea. Together, these findings are concerning for sarcoidosis, a multi-system non-caseating granulomatous disorder.  

Sarcoidosis is more common in African-Americans, and patients often have a family member with the condition as well. While the exact pathophysiology of this disease is still being studied, it is thought to be due to dendritic cell overstimulation in response to a foreign antigen, resulting in multisystem granulomatous disease. Over time, deposition of granulomas results in fibrous scar formation in affected organs—for example, causing restrictive lung disease in the lung or cardiomyopathy in the heart. Less commonly, granuloma formation in the liver can result in cholestatic liver disease and cirrhosis. Nervous system involvement commonly manifests with Bell's palsy.

Most patients with sarcoidosis are completely asymptomatic, but when symptoms do arise, they are usually constitutional. Symptoms include fever, weight loss, fatigue, arthropathy, shortness of breath and coughing. More specific signs and symptoms include erythema nodosum, lupus pernio (a lupus like rash), and uveitis.     

Option Analysis

✅ Non-caseating granulomas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Caseating granulomas:
Incorrect:Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection is associated with caseation necrosis and presents with fevers, night sweats, weight loss, as well as risk factors for acquisition such as travel to endemic areas. It is a rare cause of uveitis. 
❌ Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies :
Incorrect: Crohn disease is associated with anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies as well as anterior uveitis. This patient has some clinical features of this condition; however, she is without any gastrointestinal features, making this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ HLA-B27 surface antigen:
Incorrect: HLA-B27 surface antigen is associated with ankylosing spondylitis as well as ulcerative colitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis—all of which are clinically correlated with uveitis. However, aside from uveitis, this patient does not have typical features of these diseases.
❌ Anti-dsDNA antibodies :
Incorrect: Systemic lupus erythematosus is associated with anti-dsDNA antibodies and is rarely associated with uveitis. Additionally, patients with SLE typically present with polyarthralgias, rashes, and/or painless oral ulcers, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old African-American man presents to his primary care physician with shortness of breath and fatigue over the past several months. He complains of diffuse pain in his joints as well as a rash that appeared over his lower extremities. He reports “I’m just not feeling like myself, and I’m starting to wonder if I’m depressed.” His past medical history is notable for obesity, hypertension, and a 20-pack-year smoking history. He works as a construction contractor. Temperature 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 147/94 mmHg. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination is notable for submandibular and axillary lymphadenopathy, as well as red tender lumps on the anterior shins. He subsequently undergoes lymph node biopsy that demonstrates the following pathologic lesion:  

 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia    

Which of the following laboratory findings is most commonly associated with this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This African-American patient presents with chronic shortness of breath, fatigue, erythema nodosum (red tender lumps on the anterior shins), lymphadenopathy, as well as a histologic image demonstrating asteroid bodies consistent with sarcoidosis. Of the laboratory findings listed, hypercalcemia is most commonly found in patients with sarcoidosis due to increased expression of 1-alpha hydroxylase in alveolar macrophages. Increased 1-alpha hydroxylase results in conversion of vitamin D precursors to calcitriol and increased intestinal absorption of calcium.  


Sarcoidosis refers to a multisystem granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas in involved organs, most commonly the lungs. Diagnosis of the disease is made by confirming compatible clinical and radiographic manifestations, excluding other similar diseases, and tissue biopsy confirming detection of noncaseating granulomas.  

Laboratory findings associated with sarcoidosis include increased serum ACE levels, hypercalcemia, and an increased CD4/CD8 T-cell ratio. Additional clues to the diagnosis include radiographic findings of bilateral hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy, coarse reticular opacities, or a honeycombing pattern in the upper lobes (late finding) on chest CT. Histologic specimens contain noncaseating granulomas with associated asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies, which are calcium and protein inclusions inside of Langhans giant cells. The majority of cases resolve spontaneously without any required treatment; however, more severe cases may require treatment with steroids.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypercalcemia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eosinophilia :
Incorrect: Infections with opportunistic fungal infections, such as Aspergillus, can result in peripheral eosinophilia on a complete blood count and differential; however, opportunistic infections are rarely associated with sarcoidosis. 
❌ Overexpression of calretinin :
Incorrect: Mesothelioma is associated with an overexpression of calretinin. Histologically, it is associated with psammoma bodies. 
❌ Increased plasma 5-HIAA concentration :
Incorrect: Elevated plasma 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) can be seen in patients with carcinoid syndrome. Carcinoid tumor cells secrete excessive amounts of serotonin. If the tumor metastasizes to the lungs, patients can present with systemic symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, such as unexplained diarrhea, cutaneous flushing, and/or bronchospasm/wheezing. Although this patient has shortness of breath, this patient lacks the other suggestive symptoms, making this diagnosis unlikely.   
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect:Legionella and certain lung malignancies  (e.g. small cell carcinoma) are associated with hyponatremia—the latter due to SIADH. Hyponatremia is not commonly associated with sarcoidosis.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine visit. He reports that he is otherwise feeling well aside from a chronic cough. He reports that he continues to smoke 10-15 cigarettes per day despite attempting to quit earlier this year. His past medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. He has been working in an underground coal mine for the past twenty years. The patient has a screening chest x-ray performed which is demonstrated below.  

 

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology resulting in this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Imbalance in protease-antiprotease activity and enlargement of alveolar space
Calcification and fibrosis of the pleura
Type IV hypersensitivity reaction and granuloma formation

questions.solution:
This patient who works in a coal mine presents with a history of chronic cough and a chest x-ray that demonstrates focal nodular opacities in the upper lobes, consistent with coal workers pneumoconiosis. The underlying pathophysiology of these radiographic findings is related to an aggregation of macrophages laden with carbon.  

Coal workers pneumoconiosis, also known as black lung disease, or coal miners disease, is caused by prolonged inhalation of coal dust—usually over a time period of approximately twenty years. Coal dust that enters the lungs cannot be removed, and the particles are engulfed by resident alveolar or interstitial macrophages. Over time, coal dust provides a sufficient stimulus for the macrophage to release various inflammatory products and fibroblast growth factors, inducing further aggregation of carbon-laden macrophages called coal macules, which are often surrounded by focal emphysema.  These aggregations can cause inflammation and fibrosis, as well as the formation of nodular lesions within the lungs, typically in the upper lobes.    

Most patients with coal workers pneumoconiosis are asymptomatic, and when they do develop symptoms, it is usually in the form of chronic cough, dyspnea, or fleeting chest discomfort. Diagnosis is based on a history of exposure to coal, a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing, as well as a chest x-ray demonstrating small rounded, nodular opacities in the upper lobes. Treatment for this condition is removal from the exposure and supportive care.  



Option Analysis

✅ Aggregation of carbon laden macrophages:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Imbalance in protease-antiprotease activity and enlargement of alveolar space:
Incorrect: An imbalance in protease-antiprotease activity and enlargement of alveolar space is the primary mechanism thought to underlie the development of emphysematous changes in the lung. While this patient does smoke, the chest radiograph does not demonstrate emphysematous changes such as flattened diaphragms, large bullae, or increased retrosternal space.    
❌ Calcification and fibrosis of the pleura:
Incorrect: Calcification and fibrosis of the pleura results in pleural thickening and plaque formation, a feature unique to asbestosis. At risk individuals include those who work in shipbuilding, plumbing, or roofing.
❌ Type IV hypersensitivity reaction and granuloma formation:
Incorrect: Berylliosis is a noncaseating granulomatous disease due to exposure to beryllium—a metal found in computers, electronics, and cars. 
❌ Intraalveolar exudate :
Incorrect: A lobar pneumonia results in intra-alveolar exudate and subsequent lung consolidation, which appears as a lobar opacity on chest x-ray. This patient’s clinical presentation is inconsistent with bacterial pneumonia.

questions.text: A patient is currently being evaluated for a massive pulmonary embolism in the cardiac intensive care unit. As part of the patient’s evaluation, the jugular vein is assessed to measure jugular venous pressure.  Which of the following anatomic landmarks are best used to identify the internal jugular vein for the performance of this measurement?

choices.text: Between the medial and lateral heads of the sternocleidomastoid
1 cm inferior to the junction of the middle and medial third of the clavicle
Midline between the thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage

questions.solution:
In the neck, the sigmoid sinus exits the jugular foramen and continues in the neck to form the internal jugular vein (IJV).  The IJV travels within the carotid sheath, lateral to the internal carotid artery, with the vagus nerve sitting between the two vessels.  It joins the subclavian vein to form the brachiocephalic vein at the clavicle level.

Surgical landmarks are used to identify the jugular vein. The anterior triangle of the neck is bound inferiorly by the clavicle by the head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and laterally by the lateral head of the sternocleidomastoid. The internal carotid artery (ICA) is isolated by palpation. Lateral to the ICA lies the internal jugular vein.

JVP ( jugular venous pressure) reflects the right atrial pressure. It is frequently used clinically to assess whether the RAP is elevated (Right-sided congestive heart failure) or low (hypovolemic shock). It can also diagnose pericardial disease, tricuspid valve stenosis, and superior vena cava obstruction.

The right IJV is generally preferred to examine the jugular venous pulse as it is in line with the superior vena cava.  While examining the JVP in a patient, the examiner stands on the patient's right side with the optimal degree of upper body elevation. The degree of upper body elevation refers to the angle at which the venous meniscus is best appreciated. In most cases, it is 45 degrees.

The patient’s head is then turned away, and the head and jaw are tipped slightly upwards. Two rulers are required to assess the JVP. One ruler is placed horizontally from the highest visible pulsation point of the internal jugular vein while the other ruler is crossed at the sternal angle. The RAP is determined by adding the height of the jugular venous column above the sternal angle to the vertical distance from the right atrium to the sternal angle (5cm).  

Option Analysis

✅ Between the medial and lateral heads of the sternocleidomastoid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 1 cm inferior to the junction of the middle and medial third of the clavicle:
Incorrect: This answer describes the access route and anatomic landmarks for subclavian vein central venous access. The stem above describes central venous access obtained through the internal jugular vein.  
❌ Second intercostal space, midclavicular line:
Incorrect: This anatomic site references the site for thoracic needle decompression, not central venous access. A needle and catheter should be placed on the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damage to intercostal vasculature and nerve.  
❌ Fourth intercostal space midaxillary line:
Incorrect: This stem describes one of the anatomic sites for tube thoracostomy (chest tube placement), not central venous access.  
❌ Midline between the thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage:
Incorrect: These anatomic landmarks are used for palpation of the cricothyroid membrane--the site of access for emergent cricothyrotomy and tracheostomy placement.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man with a history of hypertension and COPD presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of chest tightness and extremity swelling. The patient reports chest tightness on his daily walk, and he noticed his legs look “puffy.” Physical exam is notable for a loud P2 heart sound, jugular venous distention, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. Laboratory examination reveals normal troponin and B-natriuretic peptide levels. An ECG is demonstrated below. The patient undergoes right heart catheterization, which shows a mean pulmonary arterial  pressure of 34 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely observation seen on histologic examination of this patient’s lungs?



Reproduced from: wikipedia

choices.text: Areas of patchy fibrosis with complete occlusion of small airways
Mucosal necrosis and sloughing of tissue into airway lumen

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of COPD presents for evaluation of chest pain and extremity swelling has several clinical findings that indicate he is suffering from symptomatic pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. The ECG with evidence of right axis deviation suggests right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH), which occurs when the right heart is forced to pump harder against a hypertensive circuit. In addition, right heart catheterization reveals the patient’s mean pulmonary arterial pressure is 34 mm Hg--which is well above a normal pulmonary artery pressure.

There are several causes of pulmonary hypertension, but the underlying pathological changes are similar. Common etiologies include left sided heart failure, as blood backs up in the pulmonary veins and capillary beds, causing increased pressures in the pulmonary arteries. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) results in reflexive pulmonary arteriole constriction and shunting of blood from diseased areas of the lung. Over time, widespread areas of the lung undergo this process, leading to an increase in pulmonary vascular resistance.

Pathological examination of lung tissue in patients with long-term pulmonary hypertension often demonstrates smooth muscle hypertrophy  of arterioles--which reflects chronic damage to endothelial cells. Important complications of pulmonary hypertension include right-sided heart failure (cor pulmonale) and pulmonary edema.



Option Analysis

✅ Hypertrophy of arteriolar smooth muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Multilobular consolidations:
Incorrect: Multilobular consolidations are consistent with an underlying infectious or neoplastic process, which are unlikely given the information provided in the stem.
❌ Areas of patchy fibrosis with complete occlusion of small airways:
Incorrect: This answer describes bronchiolitis obliterans, which does not characterize this patient’s symptomatology.
❌ Mucosal necrosis and sloughing of tissue into airway lumen:
Incorrect: This answer describes bronchial necrosis, which does not characterize this patient’s symptomatology.
❌ Loculated pleural effusions:
Incorrect: Loculated pleural effusions are found in profoundly septic patients; this patient is without other infectious findings on exam or per history.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to her primary pediatrician for evaluation of dyspnea. The patient feels tired throughout the day, despite sleeping for nine hours every night. She additionally describes intermittent trouble breathing with exertion. The patient’s mother and grandmother have suffered from similar symptoms throughout their lives and have a “problem with the vessels in our lungs.” An echocardiogram is performed, which is within normal limits. Cardiac catheterization is performed, and the patient’s mean pulmonary artery pressure is 32 mmHg (normal <25 mmHg). A mutation in which of the following genes is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This young patient is suffering from symptoms of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). While her symptomatology is minimal, early recognition of this disease process is key to prevent progression of disease. Her high mean pulmonary arterial pressure is diagnostic of pulmonary hypertension. Other members of the patient’s family also suffer from similar symptoms, which suggests an inherited pattern of disease transmission.

There are numerous underlying causes of pulmonary arterial hypertension; however, this patient's history suggests heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension (HPAH). HPAH is diagnosed via either a multigene assay or a single gene assay for genes which have been identified as possibly causing HPAH. There are currently approximately 6 genes linked to HPAH, most of which are beyond the scope of testing for board examination purposes. However, BMPR2 has the closest association with HPAH. Approximately 75% of mutant variation of BMPR2 have been shown as pathogenic variants causing HPAH.  

Option Analysis

❌ HFE:
Incorrect: Mutations in this gene are associated with hemochromatosis, not pulmonary arterial hypertension.
✅ BMPR2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HLA-DR:
Incorrect: Mutations in this gene are associated with rheumatoid arthritis and diabetes, not pulmonary arterial hypertension.
❌ COL11A2:
Incorrect: Mutations in this gene are associated with Stickler syndrome, not pulmonary arterial hypertension.
❌  CFTR:
Incorrect: Mutations in this gene are associated with cystic fibrosis, not pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath. The patient reports she was on a walk when she suddenly had sharp chest pain worse with inspiration. The patient reports she is otherwise healthy. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive pill, which she recently started taking for birth control. She is a current smoker, she drinks 3-4 beers daily and she occasionally uses cocaine. The patient reports she was recently incarcerated. While in the ED, she is noted to have an episode of hemoptysis. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 108/80 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Her chest x-ray and ECG and shown below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease process?  



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Vasospasm of a large coronary artery
Intimal dissection of the ascending aorta

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset pleuritic chest pain, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxemia in the setting of recent initiation of oral contraceptive pills, which is concerning for a pulmonary embolism. Additionally, her chest x-ray reveals a wedge-shaped infarct known as Hampton's hump (indicated by the red circle below) and an electrocardiogram with an S1Q3T3 pattern, which is consistent with right heart strain.   

Oral contraceptive pills, particularly those with a higher concentration of estrogen, are known to increase the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) as high as five-fold. The mechanism is still poorly understood, but it is thought to be due to an estrogen-induced increase in clotting factor synthesis. VTE risk may be compounded by thrombophilic disorders, active malignancies, prolonged immobilization, and recent surgery or trauma. These risk factors contribute to venous stasis, endothelial injury, and a hypercoagulable state -- also known as Virchow’s triad.  

Typically, pulmonary emboli originate in the deep veins of the leg, dislodge, and migrate upward via the vena cava to the right side of the heart. As the right heart beats, the clot propels into the pulmonary arteries, causing a ventilation-perfusion (VQ) mismatch which results in respiratory alkalosis, pleuritic chest pain, hypoxemia and a low pCO2. If the clot becomes large, the right heart may fail due to the increased strain, resulting in cor pulmonale and cardiogenic shock.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Subacute infection with a mycobacteria:
Incorrect: This patient has risk factors for tuberculosis infection, including recent incarceration. Her chest x-ray demonstrates a wedge shaped infarct known as Hamptons sign, whereas tuberculosis typically presents with bilateral infiltrates in the apical-posterior segments of the upper lobes, along with associated symptoms of weight loss, malaise, and night-sweats.   
✅ Hormone-induced thrombophilia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vasospasm of a large coronary artery:
Incorrect: Cocaine-induced vasospasm may demonstrate characteristic symptoms of acute coronary syndrome, including chest pain that is worse with exertion, pressure-like, and relieved with rest or nitroglycerin. Typically, patients will manifest ST-depressions or elevations as opposed to the pattern of right heart strain as seen on this patient’s ECG.   
❌ Intimal dissection of the ascending aorta  :
Incorrect: Cocaine and uncontrolled hypertension can manifest in aortic dissection, which typically presents with acute onset tearing chest pain radiating to the back. A chest x-ray will often demonstrate a widened mediastinum or a tortuous aorta, which is not observed in this case.   
❌ Rib fractures  :
Incorrect: Rib fractures can cause pleuritic chest pain; however, this chest x-ray is without evidence of rib fractures, and the patient has no history of recent trauma.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of fatigue and dyspnea on exertion that started five months ago. The patient previously enjoyed biking on the weekends, but she has been unable to do so because of her symptoms. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies. She is currently not taking any medications. In the office, her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 128/88 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. Physical examination is notable for diffuse skin thickening and telangiectasias. On cardiac examination, there is a loud S2 at the left upper sternal border. A chest x-ray is ordered, and the results are as follows:  



Image reproduced from Radiopedia 

Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Elevated pulmonary artery pressure on heart catheterization
Systolic displacement of the mitral valve on echocardiography
Pedunculated mass in the left atrium on echocardiography
Elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure on heart catheterization

questions.solution:
The patient has pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) secondary to diffuse scleroderma. PAH causes progressive dyspnea, fatigue, and reduced exercise tolerance. Vitals will reveal an elevated systemic blood pressure.  

PAH occurs due to a combination of factors, namely: small blood vessel damage causing intimal thickening; pulmonary fibrosis causing hypoxic vasoconstriction; and myocardial fibrosis leading to left heart dysfunction. The net result is increased pulmonary vascular resistance and elevated pulmonary arterial pressure. Over time, this process can lead to right heart failure (i.e. cor pulmonale), as the right heart is unable to pump against the high pressures of the pulmonary arterial system. Physical examination findings demonstrate right ventricular (RV) heave (parasternal heave), which is an impulse palpated to the left of the sternum; this indicates RV enlargement. Additionally, there is a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound due to increased pulmonary artery pressure.

The work-up for PAH includes first obtaining an electrocardiogram, which may show right atrial and ventricular hypertrophy as well as right axis deviation. A chest x-ray can show similar findings. Right atrial enlargement will present with increased convexity of the right heart border. Right ventricular enlargement will present with rounding of the left heart border and elevation of the cardiac apex. In addition, a prominent central pulmonary artery or peripheral hypervascularity may be seen on chest x-ray. If either of these initial tests demonstrate findings concerning for PAH, right heart catheterization should be performed. A mean pulmonary artery pressure exceeding 20 mmHg is necessary to make the diagnosis. Vasodilators (e.g., bosentan, sildenafil) are used to treat PAH. Anticoagulants (e.g. warfarin) can also be administered to decrease the risk of thromboembolic events.    

Option Analysis

❌ Left axis deviation on electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: The patient has dyspnea and new-onset hypertension in the setting of diffuse skin thickening. This raises concerns of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) secondary to systemic scleroderma. Over time, PAH can lead to right ventricle hypertrophy, not left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). LVH results in a left axis deviation on EKG and is typically seen in patients with chronic systemic hypertension and aortic stenosis.   
✅ Elevated pulmonary artery pressure on heart catheterization:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Systolic displacement of the mitral valve on echocardiography:
Incorrect: Displacement of the mitral valve during systole on echocardiography can be seen in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP). Although patients can also present with fatigue and dyspnea, this patient’s systemic findings (e.g., skin thickening, telangiectasias) are suggestive of a different underlying condition.   
❌ Pedunculated mass in the left atrium on echocardiography :
Incorrect: A cardiac myxoma is characterized by a low-pitched, mid-diastolic rumbling murmur heard over the cardiac apex. Although patients can present with dyspnea due to outflow obstruction, this patient’s systemic findings (e.g., skin thickening, telangiectasias) are suggestive of a different underlying condition.  
❌ Elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure on heart catheterization:
Incorrect: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PWCP) is an estimate of left atrial pressure, and is typically elevated in patients with a significant left-sided valvular pathology (e.g., mitral stenosis, aortic stenosis). This patient’s dyspnea, loud S2, and systemic findings are suggestive of a different underlying condition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of new onset shortness of breath and chest pain for the past 3 hours. She reports that she was walking to her car when the symptoms started, and she describes the pain as sharp and worse with deep inhalation. Additionally, she says she has been coughing up bloody mucus for the past hour. Her medical history is significant for breast cancer, for which she is currently undergoing radiation therapy. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Troponin is 0.08 ng/mL and brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) is 425 pg/mL. Which of the following is the best investigation for diagnosing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath, and she has active cancer. Her physical examination shows tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypoxia. In addition, her laboratory markers also demonstrate a mildly elevated troponin and BNP, concerning for right heart strain. For these reasons, there is concern for an acute pulmonary embolism (PE), with the gold standard diagnostic investigation being CT-pulmonary angiography.  

PEs are defined as a clot in the lung vasculature that cause a ventilation-perfusion (VQ) mismatch.  Arterial blood gas (ABG) often demonstrates respiratory alkalosis, with hypoxemia and a low pCO2. This phenomenon occurs because the clot prevents adequate perfusion of blood through the lung vasculature, resulting in decreased oxygenation of blood (hypoxemia) despite adequate ventilation. In an attempt to increase ventilation, patients will hyperventilate and blow off CO2, resulting in hypocarbia. If large enough, PEs ultimately result in the clinical features of hypoxia, tachycardia, and hypotension. However, most PEs are small and may only present with pleuritic chest pain or shortness of breath, without vital sign changes.  Thus, PEs require a high index of suspicion to diagnose.  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

Option Analysis

❌ Chest x-ray:
Incorrect: A chest x-ray can show evidence of pulmonary embolisms, including pleural effusions or wedge infarcts (termed Hampton’s sign). However, it is not the definitive test for diagnosing a pulmonary embolism.  
❌ D-dimer blood test:
Incorrect: A D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product. The test is very sensitive but not specific for a pulmonary embolism. A D-dimer blood test is preferred in cases where the likelihood of a pulmonary embolism is low.  
❌ Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) Scan:
Incorrect: A V/Q scan is a type of medical imaging using scintigraphy and medical isotopes to evaluate the circulation of air and blood within a patient’s lung. They are often used in patients who cannot tolerate a CT-scan with contrast, due to reduced kidney function and the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. In this patient with otherwise normal kidney function, CT-pulmonary angiography is the correct test.  
❌ Rigid bronchoscopy:
Incorrect: Rigid bronchoscopy is the preferred procedure for the removal of aspirated foreign objects and massive hemoptysis (>600 cm3 of blood loss through the pulmonary vasculature in the past 24 hours). It is not indicated in the diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism, and this patient’s hemoptysis has only been present for an hour.  
✅ CT-pulmonary angiography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of shortness of breath. The symptoms have been worsening gradually over the past several months. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder and asthma. Current medications include albuterol and sertraline. The patient’s temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 137/85 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 81% on ambient air. On physical examination, the patient appears to be in mild distress. Cardiovascular examination is notable for jugular venous distension. Scattered expiratory wheezes are heard bilaterally on auscultation of lungs. Abdominal examination reveals a liver edge that is palpable inferior to the rib cage. There is mild lower extremity pitting edema bilaterally. ECG shows right axis deviation. Echocardiography reveals right ventricular dilation with increased wall thickness. The patient is admitted and, after further work-up, started on sildenafil. Which of the following is a common adverse effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with progressive exertional dyspnea and right axis deviation on ECG, in combination with right ventricular dilation and increased wall thickness on echocardiography, is suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. After further workup, the patient is started on sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor. The other important medication of this class is tadalafil.   

PDE-5, which is normally responsible for the breakdown of cGMP, is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors, with a resultant decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP and increase in nitric oxide activity in vascular smooth muscle cells. The net result is pulmonary vasodilation and an increase in the blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis. That is why most of the PDE-5 inhibitors are FDA-approved for the use in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension and erectile dysfunction.   

Common side effects include facial flushing, headache, dyspepsia, hearing loss, and hypotension (in combination with nitrates or alpha-blockers). Sildenafil cross-reacts with the PDE-6 inhibitor in the retina and can cause transient blue vision. Rarely, nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) is also seen.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hepatotoxicity :
Incorrect: Bosentan, an endothelin-receptor antagonist can help improve symptoms in patients with pulmonary hypertension. Major adverse effects include hepatotoxicity and peripheral edema. Patients should be monitored monthly with liver function tests. PDE-5 inhibitors do not usually cause hepatotoxicity. 
✅ Blue-tinged vision :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Serotonin syndrome :
Incorrect: Sildenafil is not a serotonergic drug. Using this in combination with sertraline is not associated with any adverse effects. 
❌ Priapism :
Incorrect: Priapism refers to prolonged erection lasting more than four to six hours and can occur in men who use intrapenile alprostadil. It is uncommon with intravenous or oral administration. 
❌ Severe hypotension :
Incorrect: PDE-5 inhibitors, when used in combination with nitrates, can lead to severe hypotension due to the accumulation of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells. However, this patient is not taking nitrates and is unlikely to develop severe hypotension.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of six months of progressive shortness of breath. The patient’s past medical history is significant for acute submassive pulmonary embolism that was treated with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator nine months ago. She was taking oral contraceptive pills at the time and presented after a six-hour-long drive. After further workup, the diagnosis of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension is made. Based on cardiothoracic surgery evaluation, she is deemed to not be a surgical candidate for thromboembolectomy. The physician discusses starting a new medication that is a soluble guanylyl cyclase stimulator and helps improve exercise capacity, pulmonary hemodynamics, and time to clinical worsening. Which of the following is the most likely medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressive shortness of breath after recovering from acute pulmonary embolism recently is concerning. She is diagnosed with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH). Management of CTEPH typically includes thromboembolectomy. However, if the patient is not a surgical candidate (as in this case), they should be evaluated for medical management.        

Riociguat is a stimulator of soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC). The agent exhibits a dual mode of action; it sensitizes sGC to endogenous nitric oxide (NO), and it also directly stimulates sGC independently of NO. This drug has been shown to increase the walking distance and decrease the time to clinical worsening for patients with CTEPH; it is the only FDA-approved medication for this disease.   

Option Analysis

❌ Omalizumab :
Incorrect: Omalizumab is a IgE binding monoclonal antibody that decreases airway inflammation and is effective in the treatment of asthma that is unresponsive to other medications. It plays no role in chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH). 
❌ Filgrastim :
Incorrect: Filgrastim is a granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) that is effective in the management of leukopenia. It does not affect soluble guanylyl cyclase. 
❌ Degarelix :
Incorrect: Degarelix is a GnRH agonist that is sometimes used in the management of prostate cancer. It has no role in CTEPH. 
❌ Tizanidine :
Incorrect: Tizanidine is a centrally-acting alpha-2 agonist that is indicated in the management of muscle spasticity, multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and cerebral palsy. It is not indicated in CTEPH. 
✅ Riociguat :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office because of progressive exertional dyspnea. The patient has had dyspnea over the past year that has progressively worsened in the last two months, making it difficult to walk the half a block to the local convenience store without having to rest. The patient has not had a cough, fever, or leg swelling. Past medical history is unremarkable and the patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 23 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals a loud S2 at the left upper sternal border. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Chest x-ray is normal. ECG shows right axis deviation. Echocardiography reveals right ventricular dilation with increased wall thickness and peak tricuspid regurgitant velocity of 3.5 m/s. After further work-up, the physician decides to start the patient on selexipag. This medication is most likely to help this patient via which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Increasing cAMP-mediated bronchial smooth muscle relaxation

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with progressive exertional dyspnea and right axis deviation on ECG, in combination with echocardiographic findings of right ventricular dilation with increased wall thickness and peak tricuspid regurgitant velocity of 3.5 m/s are virtually diagnostic of pulmonary hypertension. After ruling out secondary causes with further workup, diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is made and the patient is started on selexipag.       

Selexipag, epoprostenol, treprostinil, beraprost, and inhaled iloprost are analogues of prostacyclin, an endogenous product of arachidonic acid metabolism in the vascular endothelium that is known to cause pulmonary vasodilation. These are the approved medications for the treatment of PAH. They are shown to inhibit smooth muscle proliferation and platelet aggregation by the stimulation of intracellular cAMP. Selexipag and treprostinil are available in oral formulations, while epoprostenol is intravenous medication that is reserved for severe PAH.       

Besides PAH, prostacyclin analogs are sometimes indicated in patients with right heart failure. Common side effects include thrombocytopenia and bleeding, jaw pain, leg pain, flushing, headache, nausea, and vomiting.   

Option Analysis

❌ Decreasing airway inflammation :
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin E (IgE) binding monoclonal antibodies (e.g. omalizumab), decrease airway inflammation and are effective in the treatment of asthma that is unresponsive to other medications. They have no role in the management of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). 
❌ Increasing cAMP-mediated bronchial smooth muscle relaxation :
Incorrect: Beta-2 receptor agonists act by increasing cAMP-mediated bronchial smooth muscle relaxation and are effective in treating asthma. They have no role in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). 
❌ Decreasing airway collagen deposition :
Incorrect: Decreasing airway collagen deposition by tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g. imatinib) is effective to slow the progression of pulmonary fibrosis. It plays no role in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). 
✅ Increasing pulmonary vasodilation :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Decreasing alveolar destruction :
Incorrect: Alveolar destruction can be decreased in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) by smoking cessation. It plays no role in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate a fever and cough. The patient has been experiencing ongoing fevers for the past week.
