She also has a productive cough that yields greenish sputum. Past medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 105/min, blood pressure is 100/66 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Upright AP and lateral chest radiographs are obtained and demonstrated below. Which of the following anatomic locations is the most likely site for pulmonary auscultation of this patient’s pathology?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Right anterior mid clavicular line, 5th intercostal space
Right posterior mid scapular line, 5th intercostal space
Right anterior mid clavicular line, 2nd intercostal space
Right posterior mid scapular line at the level of the 10th thoracic vertebra
Right anterior midaxillary line, 6th intercostal space

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features of pneumonia and a right middle lobe consolidation on chest radiography. The anatomic area for pulmonary auscultation of this pathology is over the right anterior midclavicular line in the fifth intercostal space.  

The lung is divided into several lobes, which are separated by fissures. In both lungs, the oblique fissure runs posteriorly at the level of T3 to the 6th rib anteriorly at the midclavicular line. The horizontal fissure, which separates the superior and middle lobes of the right lung, connects to the right oblique fissure at the midaxillary line near the 5th rib and runs anteriorly to the area of the 4th costal cartilage. Ultimately, these anatomic distinctions create an approach for pulmonary auscultation: most posterior auscultation examines the inferior lobes, whereas anterior auscultation primarily concerns the superior and middle lobes.  

Auscultation should be performed sequentially from the lung apices to the lungs bases. Auscultation should be performed on both the anterior and posterior chest, and sounds of the left chest should be compared to those of the right. Auscultating in this manner will ensure comprehensive examination and evaluation of all the relevant anatomical components of the lungs.    



Option Analysis

✅ Right anterior mid clavicular line, 5th intercostal space:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Right posterior mid scapular line, 5th intercostal space:
Incorrect: The right middle lobe is best auscultated anteriorly over the fourth or fifth intercostal space, midclavicular line. Posterior auscultation will typically only reveal abnormalities of the superior and inferior lobes of the right lung.
❌ Right anterior mid clavicular line, 2nd intercostal space :
Incorrect: This anatomic location is most effective for auscultating the superior lobe of the right lung, not the right middle lobe.
❌ Right posterior mid scapular line at the level of the 10th thoracic vertebra:
Incorrect: This anatomic location is the best space for auscultating the lung bases, not the right middle lobe.
❌ Right anterior midaxillary line, 6th intercostal space :
Incorrect: This space describes the most appropriate area for auscultation of the inferior lobe of the right lung, not the right middle lobe.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to evaluate shortness of breath. The parent is at the bedside and states, “I saw him lying on his right side putting plastic beads in his mouth. I think he swallowed one of them.” The patient is otherwise healthy, and his vaccinations are up to date. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 95/50 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is intermittently tachypneic. Faint stridor is present on pulmonary auscultation. The foreign body was most likely aspirated into which anatomic lung region?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after an aspiration event while in the right lateral decubitus position. Of the anatomic sites listed above, the most likely aspiration area is the dependent region of the right upper lobe.   

Aspiration of foreign bodies, vomitus, or oral secretions is a common event. The aspiration site can be predicted based on the patient’s position when the aspiration event occurs. The right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and has a more vertical trajectory than the left mainstem bronchus. As a result, aspirated foreign bodies are more likely to enter and lodge in the right bronchus or one of its branches.  

In addition to this anatomic preference, aspirated foreign bodies follow gravity, resulting in foreign bodies in the dependent portions of the lung. In the supine position, the dependent lung segments are the posterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes. In contrast, individuals in an upright position will most likely aspirate into the basilar segments of the right lower lobe. Finally, the aspirate usually enters the right upper lobe when lying on the right side.   

Option Analysis

✅ Right upper lobe:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right lower lobe :
Incorrect: Aspiration in the upright position is likely to result in the foreign object being lodged in the right lower lobe, not the upper lobes. However, this patient aspirated while in a right lateral decubitus position.
❌ Left lower lobe:
Incorrect: Aspiration is always less likely to occur in the left lower lobe because the right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and has a more vertical trajectory. In addition, this patient aspirated while in a right lateral decubitus position, making the right upper lobe the most likely site of aspiration.
❌ Right middle lobe :
Incorrect: Aspiration into the right middle lobe is uncommon, regardless of anatomic position. 
❌ Left upper lobe:
Incorrect: Aspiration into the left upper lobe does not readily occur. Instead, aspiration is more likely to involve the right lung since the right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and has a more vertical trajectory.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of worsening productive cough and fevers over the last few days. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension that is well-controlled with metoprolol. He recently completed a course of antibiotics for cellulitis of the left shin. He actively smokes, has a 15-pack-year smoking history, and drinks 2-3 beers on the weekends. He rarely exercises. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals dullness to percussion and bronchial breath sounds over the left lung. Chest radiograph demonstrates a left lower lobe consolidation. Sputum microscopy shows Gram-positive diplococci. Which of the following is the most important risk factor for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fevers, productive cough, and lobar consolidation, which are all suggestive of pneumonia. The presence of Gram-positive diplococci in the sputum indicates the underlying pathogen is most likely Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is one of the most common causes of community-acquired pneumonia. 

The innate defense mechanisms of the airways and lungs include the cough reflex, gag reflex (also termed pharyngeal reflex), mucociliary clearance, as well as the epithelial barrier itself. Therefore, alterations in the function of these protective factors can predispose individuals to developing pneumonia and other respiratory infections. For instance, mucociliary clearance occurs by organized ciliary movements that facilitate removal of inhaled pathogens and particulate material from the distal airway toward the pharynx. Smoking can impair mucociliary clearance by causing mucus overproduction and decreased ciliary beat frequency. Additionally, alcohol abuse can cause decreased cough and gag reflexes, thereby increasing the risk for pathogen aspiration or inhalation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Alcohol use :
Incorrect: Chronic alcohol use is a risk factor for developing aspiration pneumonia since alcohol intoxication can lead to impaired cough and gag reflexes. However, this patient consumes 2-3 beers/week, which would not be enough to cause significant intoxication. Furthermore, aspiration pneumonia is typically caused by the mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria that are found in the oral flora. 
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension has not been demonstrated to be a significant risk factor for developing pneumonia. 
❌ Sedentary lifestyle:
Incorrect: Although a sedentary lifestyle can predispose patients to more severe forms of cardiovascular disease, it is not a significant risk factor for developing pneumonia. 
✅ Cigarette smoking :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent antibiotic use:
Incorrect: Recent antibiotic use can increase a patient's risk for Clostridium difficile diarrhea. However, it is not known to be a risk factor for developing pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a worsening cough, shortness of breath, and night sweats. In addition, the patient has experienced a 10 lb weight loss over the past 2 months despite having made no changes to her diet. She was recently released from incarceration and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient was born in Mexico and had a positive PPD test as an adolescent. Chest x-ray is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  

Which of the following best describes the radiographic finding above?

choices.text: Calcified mycobacterial lesion and bilateral calcified hilar lymph nodes
Hilar lymphadenopathy and a primary focus of mycobacterial infection
Fibrocaseous cavitary lesion in the upper lobes

questions.solution:
This patient has findings concerning for pulmonary tuberculosis including night sweats, fevers, and cough. The chest x-ray demonstrates a calcified lesion in the axillary region of the right lung field and ipsilateral calcified hilar lymph nodes, which is referred to as a Ranke complex.   

There are three progressive lesions noted in pulmonary tuberculosis: Ghon focus, Ghon complex, and Ranke Complex. A Ghon focus appears first and is characterized by a primary granulomatous infection filled with mycobacteria. As mycobacteria escape into nearby pulmonary lymph nodes, they enlarge and can become radiographically apparent. Together, a Ghon focus and hilar lymphadenopathy is referred to as a Ghon complex and is typical of primary pulmonary tuberculosis. Over time, the Ghon complex scars, becomes calcified, and is even more radiographically apparent. This pathologic variant is then referred to as a Ranke complex, which generally contains less mycobacteria than a Ghon complex but can still yield features of active pulmonary tuberculosis.  

Figure 1: Calcified granuloma (circle) and calcified hilar lymph nodes (arrows) consistent with Ranke complex


Option Analysis

✅ Calcified mycobacterial lesion and bilateral calcified hilar lymph nodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hilar lymphadenopathy and a primary focus of mycobacterial infection:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the findings associated with a Ghon complex, which is associated with primary pulmonary tuberculosis and is the precursor to a Ranke complex. However, this patient has a calcified granuloma in the axillary region of the right lung field and calcified right hilar lymph nodes, which is more consistent with the presentation of a Ranke complex.
❌ Primary focus of mycobacterial infection :
Incorrect: A primary focus of mycobacterial infection is referred to as a Ghon focus. It is essentially a granuloma filled with mycobacteria. This pathologic feature is usually not visible on plain radiographs unless it becomes large. In contrast, this patient has a calcified granuloma in the axillary region of the right lung field and calcified right hilar lymph nodes, which is more consistent with the presentation of a Ranke complex.
❌ Cavitary caseating lesion:
Incorrect: Cavitary necrotic tuberculous lesions more typically occur due to secondary tuberculosis. Radiographically they appear as a hyperlucent region of the lung contained within a consolidation or mass.  
❌ Fibrocaseous cavitary lesion in the upper lobes:
Incorrect: A lesion of the upper lobes of the lung is more indicative of secondary or reactivation tuberculosis. Typically, patients will have a history of untreated tuberculosis with recrudescent symptoms.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of fevers and a productive cough that have been ongoing for the past three days. She has not experienced hemoptysis, recent weight loss, or night sweats. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus. She has a 20-pack-year smoking history. She worked as a plumber for 30 years. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/88 mmHg. Physical examination reveals dullness to percussion and bronchial breath sounds over the right lung. Chest radiograph reveals a right lower lobe consolidation. Sputum microscopy shows Gram-positive diplococci. Which of the following histopathological changes is most likely present in the affected lung lobe?

choices.text: Hyaline membrane formation and intraalveolar protein-rich edema
Enlargement of air spaces with destruction of alveolar septa
Interstitial fibrosis with golden-brown beaded rods
Accumulation of eosinophils within lung parenchyma
Alveolar spaces filled with neutrophils and fibrin

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fevers, productive cough, and lobar consolidation, which are suggestive of pneumonia. Additionally, the presence of Gram-positive diplococci in the sputum indicates the underlying pathogen is likely Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia.

Pneumonia is an infectious process resulting from the invasion and overgrowth of microorganisms in the lung parenchyma, which leads to intraalveolar exudate formation. Lobar pneumonia is classically described as having 4 stages:

  1.  The first stage is congestion. It occurs between days 1-2 and is when blood vessels and alveoli start filling with excess fluid.  
  2.  The next stage is red hepatization and occurs between days 3-4. This stage is when exudate, which contains red blood cells, neutrophils, and fibrin, starts filling airspaces and makes them more solid. The term hepatization refers to the lungs taking on a liver-like appearance due to the accumulation of reddish-brown exudate.  
  3.  The third stage is gray hepatization, which occurs around days 5-7. In this stage, the lungs are still firm but become pale gray because the red blood cells in the exudate begin breaking down.  
  4. The last stage is resolution, which occurs around day 8 and can continue for 3 weeks. In this stage, the exudate is digested by enzymes, ingested by macrophages, or coughed up.


Option Analysis

❌ Hyaline membrane formation and intraalveolar protein-rich edema:
Incorrect: This finding is seen in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which could be a severe complication in some cases of pneumonia. However, this patient’s chest radiograph lacks the bilateral patchy infiltrates that are characteristic of ARDS.
❌ Enlargement of air spaces with destruction of alveolar septa :
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with pulmonary emphysema. Although this patient has an extensive smoking history, the acute nature of the illness and radiographic findings demonstrating lobar consolidation are more consistent with community-acquired pneumonia.
❌ Interstitial fibrosis with golden-brown beaded rods :
Incorrect: This histopathological finding can be seen in patients with asbestosis. Although this patient may have had occupational exposure to asbestos (e.g. as a plumber), the acute nature of the illness is more consistent with community-acquired pneumonia. 
❌ Accumulation of eosinophils within lung parenchyma:
Incorrect: This histopathological finding is consistent with eosinophilic lung disease. The condition can be idiopathic, due to autoimmune reactions, or due to drug side effects. However, this patient has a fever, productive cough, and chest radiograph demonstrating lobar consolidation, which is more consistent with bacterial pneumonia. 
✅ Alveolar spaces filled with neutrophils and fibrin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician for evaluation of sore throat. Around a week ago, he began experiencing difficulty swallowing due to pain. He has also had associated fevers, fatigue, and anorexia. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. He does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. The patient is sexually active with one female partner. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/71 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates tender posterior auricular and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, as well as bilateral tonsillar swelling with exudates. A screening heterophile antibody test returns positive. Which of the following clinical features represents a potentially life-threatening complication of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Left upper quadrant pain referred to the left shoulder
Pseudomembrane formation in the posterior oropharynx
Descending paralysis affecting the facial muscles

questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents with sore throat, fevers, malaise, and posterior lymphadenopathy. Furthermore, the heterophile antibody screen is positive. In combination, these findings are suggestive of infectious mononucleosis. One potentially lethal post-infectious complication is splenic rupture, which can present with pain in the left upper abdominal quadrant with referred pain to the shoulder due to subdiaphragmatic hemoperitoneum.

Infectious mononucleosis refers to an acute illness caused most commonly by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The disease is usually transmitted via oral secretions, such as from kissing or sharing glasses. It can present with fever, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, tonsillitis, and tonsillar swelling with exudate. In addition to the aforementioned clinical features, an important differentiating finding includes the presence of posterior cervical or auricular lymphadenopathy, which is rare in streptococcal pharyngitis or other forms of viral pharyngitis. Furthermore, patients with infectious mononucleosis can develop hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.

The most important complication associated with infectious mononucleosis is splenic rupture. To avoid this potentially fatal complication, patients should be instructed to avoid all sports-related activities for at least three weeks after symptom onset and all contact sports for at least four weeks.

Option Analysis

✅ Left upper quadrant pain referred to the left shoulder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bilateral facial nerve palsy:
Incorrect: Infection by Borrelia burgdorferi can result in Lyme disease. If untreated, Lyme disease can cause sequelae including facial nerve palsy, arthritis, and atrioventricular heart block. However, facial nerve palsy is largely non-lethal and is overall a rare post-infectious complication of infectious mononucleosis.
❌ Pseudomembrane formation in the posterior oropharynx:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranes are composed of necrotic fibrin, leukocytes, erythrocytes, epithelial cells, and bacteria. The finding develops after infection by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and can potentially cause respiratory distress. However, pseudomembranes do not develop following Epstein-Barr virus infection.
❌ Choreiform and repetitive motor movements :
Incorrect: Pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder associated with group A streptococci  (PANDAS) refers to a rare post-infectious complication of streptococcal pharyngitis. Patients with PANDAS can manifest with obsessive-compulsive behavior, tics, and motor hyperactivity (e.g. fidgeting). However, the condition is not a complication of infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epsitein-Barr virus.
❌ Descending paralysis affecting the facial muscles:
Incorrect: In rare cases, the Epstein-Barr virus can cause Guillain-Barre syndrome, which manifests with an ascending paralysis. In contrast, a descending paralysis is more concerning for botulism caused by the bacteria Clostridium botulinum.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency room for facial pain, weakness, and malaise. She also has a throbbing headache. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and HIV infection. Home medications include zidovudine, lamivudine, lopinavir, ritonavir and metformin. However, she admits to poor compliance with the medications. The patient’s CD4 count is 121 cells/mm3, and viral load is 50,000. Physical examination shows exquisite tenderness to palpation over the right maxillary sinus. Additionally, there is a black eschar over her nares and palate. Which of the following symptoms would suggest a severe complication of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has facial pain, headache, and a black eschar in the setting of poorly controlled HIV and diabetes. She most likely has rhinosinusitis secondary to mucormycosis infection.

Rhinosinusitis describes inflammation of the mucosal lining of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. It can lead to edema, increased mucus production, hyposmia, and erythema over the affected sinuses. Infection of the ethmoid sinuses can result in nasal bridge and retro-orbital pain. Likewise, infections in the sphenoid or ethmoid sinuses may present similarly, but these infections can extend to the cavernous sinus and cause cavernous sinus syndrome, a severe complication that can manifest with multiple cranial nerve palsies.

This patient’s history of immunosuppression (e.g. poorly controlled HIV) and diabetes places her at risk of mucormycosis, which is an infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales. Mucor and Rhizopus species are most frequently implicated. The condition classically presents with a black necrotic eschar on the face. The infection is aggressive and can spread to adjacent structures such as the orbits and brain. As a result, it is typically managed with surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration. 

Option Analysis

❌ Altered mental status:
Incorrect: Altered mental status can be due to a variety of factors, including severe illness, medications, malnutrition, and pain. The finding is fairly nonspecific and, by itself, would not raise concerns for a severe complication of mucormycosis sinusitis.
❌ Blood-tinged nasal discharge:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are most consistent with mucormycosis sinusitis. The pathogen is aggressive and can invade surrounding tissue, resulting in blood-tinged nasal discharge. However, this would not be the most severe complication amongst the answer choices.
✅ Impaired extraocular eye movements:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Retro-orbital pain:
Incorrect: Sinusitis affecting the ethmoid sinuses can manifest with nasal bridge or retro-orbital pain. While this symptom may cause discomfort to the patient, it would not be the most severe complication amongst the answer choices.
❌ Reduced ability to detect odors:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the nasal mucosa can result in hyposmia or anosmia. This symptom is a relatively mild finding and would not suggest that there is a major complication of the patient’s mucormycosis sinusitis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for dyspnea and wheezing. The patient is diagnosed with a COPD exacerbation. Despite appropriate medical management, endotracheal intubation is required for 2 days. On the 6th day of hospitalization, as he is recovering, he develops a fever with increasing productive cough. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 121/75 mmHg. A chest radiograph reveals new, dense infiltrates in the left lower lobe with no blunting of the costophrenic angle. Sputum microscopy shows Gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following physical findings are likely to be present on physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, purulent respiratory secretions, and new pulmonary infiltrates in the left lower lobe. He likely has related to his recent mechanical ventilation or hospitalization. In patients with lobar consolidation, the following physical exam findings may be present over the affected area:  

  •  Dullness to percussion occurs because air in the alveoli is replaced by exudate and fluid. Therefore, sound will lose its normal tympanic quality. 
  •  Tactile fremitus is when there are increased vibrations felt on the patient's chest during low frequency vocalization, such as when the patient says “99.” This phenomenon occurs because sound waves travel better through the fluid-filled consolidated tissue than air-filled healthy tissue.  
  •  Similarly, bronchophony and bronchial breath sounds are characterized by increased transmission of voice and sounds produced by air movement within the affected area.  
  •  Egophony is caused by conversion of high-frequency sounds to lower-frequency sounds during auscultation due to transmission through consolidated areas. As a result, when patients say the letter “E,” it will sound like the letter “A.”  
  • Crackles are popping sounds made when air passes through fluid in collapsed alveoli. 


Option Analysis

❌   Percussion  Fremitus  Normal  Normal  :
Incorrect: These physical examination findings are likely to be present in a healthy lung. This patient has a history and radiographic findings consistent with pneumonia, which makes another set of physical exam findings more likely. 
✅  Percussion  Fremitus  Dull Increased:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Percussion  Fremitus  Hyperresonant Decreased:
Incorrect: These findings are likely to be present in patients with pneumothorax. Although mechanical ventilation increases the risk of barotrauma and can lead to pneumothorax, this patient is no longer ventilated and has clinical findings more suggestive of pneumonia.
❌  Percussion  Fremitus  Hyperresonant Increased:
Incorrect: This patient has fever, purulent secretions, and chest radiograph demonstrating a new infiltration. These findings are concerning for pneumonia, which would not present with the physical exam findings described in this answer choice.
❌   Percussion  Fremitus  Dull Decreased  :
Incorrect: These physical exam findings are likely to be present in patients with pleural effusion, which is characterized by the accumulation of fluid between the pleural layers. The pleural fluid separates the lung tissue from the body wall, leading to diminished sound transmission.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of sore throat and fever, which have been ongoing for three days. The patient states that every time she swallows, “It feels like knives are going down my throat.” However, she has not experienced any coughing. Her symptoms have not improved with over the counter acetaminophen. Past medical history is noncontributory. She does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 115/67 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for tender submandibular and anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Examination of the oropharynx reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons


A heterophile antibody screen is performed and returns negative. If untreated,this patient is at risk for developing which of the following clinical findings?

choices.text: Anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury

questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents with fever, sore throat, and evidence of anterior lymphadenopathy and tonsillar exudate on examination. The patient’s heterophile antibody screen is negative, making infectious mononucleosis an unlikely diagnosis. Together these findings are consistent with Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis, which can cause post-infectious complications such as glomerulonephritis.

Streptococcal pharyngitis is a condition that typically affects children and young adults. It clinically manifests with fever, tonsillar swelling with exudates, and tender anterior lymphadenopathy. Additional, but less common, symptoms include non-specific abdominal pain, nausea, headache, and palatal petechiae.

If the condition is not treated with antibiotics, suppurative and nonsuppurative complications of infection may arise. Suppurative complications include peritonsillar or tonsillar abscesses, sinusitis, otitis media, and systemic bacteremia. Non-suppurative complications of include rheumatic fever, scarlet fever, streptococcal toxic shock syndrome, and poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).  

Option Analysis

✅ Brown-colored urine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) can arise as a sequelae of infection by Escherichia coli O157:H7. The condition occurs when the Shiga-like toxin induces microthrombi formation on damaged blood vessels. HUS can manifest with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.
❌ Facial nerve palsy:
Incorrect: Infection by Borrelia burgdorferi can result in Lyme disease. If untreated, Lyme disease can cause sequelae including facial nerve palsy, arthritis, and atrioventricular heart block. However, facial nerve palsy is not a known post-infectious complication of Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis.
❌ Bilateral lower extremity weakness:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome is not typically associated with Streptococcus pyogenes infection but rather with Campylobacter jejuni infection.
❌ Splenomegaly:
Incorrect: Splenomegaly is a known complication of infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Streptococcal pharyngitis and mononucleosis can be difficult to distinguish clinically. However, patients with mononucleosis will often have a positive heterophile antibody screen and occipital/posterior lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with a past medical medical history of HIV, type I diabetes mellitus, and polysubstance abuse presents to the emergency department with worsening cough and night-sweats. He has been unable to sleep at night due to the cough. The patient has occasionally noticed blood in his sputum. He is currently undomiciled, drinks several beers daily, and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. The patient’s temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 136/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. A screening PPD test is positive. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for the development of this patient's disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient who is HIV positive and undomiciled presents with cough, night sweats, and a positive purified protein derivative test. These findings are concerning for active tuberculosis infection. Among this patient’s risk factors, HIV infection carries the highest risk for developing active pulmonary disease.  

Risk factors for tuberculosis include patient-related risk factors and exposure-related risk factors. Homeless populations, prisoners, healthcare workers, and those from endemic countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis have increased exposure-related risk. Patient-related risk factors that lend toward progression to active infection include systemic diseases (e.g., COPD, diabetes, ESRD), active immunosuppression or HIV infection, extremes of age, and substance use.    

Option Analysis

✅ HIV :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Homelessness:
Incorrect: Homeless populations, as well as prisoners, healthcare workers, and those from endemic countries, are at risk for exposure to tuberculosis. However, immunosuppression is a stronger risk factor for the development of active disease.
❌ Diabetes mellitus  :
Incorrect: Patients with underlying chronic diseases such as diabetes, end-stage renal disease (ESRD), and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are at risk for developing active tuberculosis. However, HIV infection is the strongest risk factor.   
❌ Active smoking:
Incorrect: Substance use, including smoking and drinking alcohol (>40 g/day) can predispose patients to developing active tuberculosis, but it is not the strongest risk factor for active disease.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Those at the extremes of age are more susceptible to active tuberculosis infections. However, age is not the strongest risk factor.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman goes to the emergency department for evaluation of productive cough and shortness of breath, which have been going on for the past 3 days. She has also experienced chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration. Past medical history is significant for persistent atrial fibrillation that has been well-controlled with amiodarone. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit substances. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 98/min, blood pressure is 138/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. A chest x-ray is obtained and demonstrates the following finding:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pneumonia is an infectious process resulting from the invasion and overgrowth of microorganisms within the lung parenchyma. Pneumonia can be characterized by the location in which the infection occurs. In bronchopneumonia, the infection is patchy throughout the lungs and involves the bronchioles as well as alveoli. In atypical or interstitial pneumonia, the infection is mainly outside the alveoli and in the interstitium. Finally, in lobar pneumonia, the infection causes consolidation within a lobe of the lung, meaning the entire consolidated area is filled with fluid. The patient in this vignette has lobar pneumonia, and the area of consolidation is identified by the red circle (Figure 1).

Usually, lobar pneumonia is described as having 4 stages: 

  1.  The first stage is congestion. It occurs between days 1-2, when blood vessels and alveoli start filling with excess fluid.  
  2.  The next stage is red hepatization and occurs between days 3-4, when exudate, which contains red blood cells, neutrophils, and fibrin, starts filling airspaces, making them more solid. The name hepatization refers to the lungs taking on a liver-like appearance due to the accumulation of reddish-brown exudate.  
  3.  The third stage is gray hepatization, which occurs around days 5-7. In this stage, the lungs are still firm but become pale gray because the red blood cells in the exudate begin breaking down.  
  4.  The last stage is resolution, which occurs around day 8 and can continue for 3 weeks. In this stage, the exudate is digested by enzymes, ingested by macrophages, and/or coughed up. 
 Figure 1: Lobar pneumonia within right middle lobe  
 


Option Analysis

❌ Bronchopneumonia:
Incorrect: Bronchopneumonia is characterized by multiple opacifications throughout the lungs due to  bronchiole as well as alveoli involvement. This patient’s infiltrate is localized to a single lobe, which is more consistent with the imaging findings of lobar pneumonia.
❌ Drug-induced pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Although this patient is at risk for amiodarone-induced pulmonary fibrosis, the acuity of her symptoms and presence of consolidation in the right lung are more suggestive of pneumonia. Pulmonary fibrosis typically presents as dyspnea that progresses over a period of months, not days.
❌ Interstitial pneumonia:
Incorrect: In atypical or interstitial pneumonia, the infection prominently affects the interstitium. Imaging will reveal reticular (web-like) infiltrates spread throughout the lungs but are often concentrated in the perihilar regions. In contrast, this patient’s imaging findings are more suggestive of lobar pneumonia. 
✅ Lobar pneumonia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sarcoidosis:
Incorrect: The acuity of this patient’s symptoms is more suggestive of pneumonia. Sarcoidosis typically presents with dyspnea that progresses over a period of months, not days. Furthermore, chest radiographs typically show hilar lymphadenopathy with or without bilateral reticular opacities, as opposed to lobar consolidation.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the university health center for evaluation of sore throat. The patient has been experiencing worsening sore throat, fatigue, and swollen lymph nodes over the past 10-days. In addition, he has been experiencing a mild cough. His symptoms have not been relieved with over the counter tylenol or with the amoxicillin prescribed by his primary care physician, which resulted in the development of an erythematous, maculopapular rash. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/71 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates tender submandibular and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharyngeal examination reveals bilateral tonsillar swelling with exudate. Which of the following clinical features can best help differentiate this patient’s disease process from other causes of pharyngitis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, sore throat, and tender lymphadenopathy. In addition, he underwent a trial of antibiotics that proved unresponsive and resulted in a maculopapular rash. In combination, these findings are suspicious for infectious mononucleosis. Among the patient’s symptoms, the presence of posterior cervical lymphadenopathy has the highest clinical correlation and positive likelihood ratio (LR) for infectious mononucleosis.

Infectious mononucleosis is an acute illness most commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). It is characterized by fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar exudate with swelling. While evaluating a patient with the aforementioned symptoms, multiple differential diagnoses should also be suspected including streptococcal pharyngitis, viral pharyngitis, acute HIV infection, and lymphoma.

Features that can help distinguish infectious mononucleosis from other causes of pharyngitis include the presence of hepatomegaly (LR 95% CI: 1.4-2.9), splenomegaly (LR 95% CI: 1.9-6.6), palatal petechiae (LR 95% CI: 2.1-13), and posterior cervical adenopathy (LR 95% CI: 1.6-5.9). In contrast, the absence of these symptoms makes the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis less likely. If a patient with infectious mononucleosis is misdiagnosed with streptococcal pharyngitis, administration of amoxicillin can precipitate a diffuse maculopapular rash. 

Option Analysis

✅ Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior cervical lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Anterior cervical lymphadenopathy is observed in both bacterial and viral pharyngitis, as well as in infectious mononucleosis. As a result, this physical examination finding is non-specific and would not help in distinguishing infectious mononucleosis from other causes of pharyngitis.
❌ Tonsillar exudate:
Incorrect: This patient presents with sore throat, tonsillar swelling with exudate, as well as submandibular and posterior auricular lymphadenopathy. These findings are concerning for infectious mononucleosis. The presence of tonsillar exudate, however, does not reliably distinguish infectious mononucleosis from other causes of pharyngitis.
❌ Fatigue:
Incorrect: Patients with infectious mononucleosis can present with fatigue. However, fatigue is also observed in patients with other causes of pharyngitis (e.g. streptococcal pharyngitis). As a result, this symptom has limited utility in identifying the underlying cause of this patient’s pharyngitis.
❌ Presence of cough:
Incorrect: According to the Centor score, the presence of a cough leans against streptococcal pharyngitis. However, this symptom does not reliably rule in or out infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the primary care physician with fevers, cough, and night sweats. He is accompanied by his aunt, who reports the patient has been coughing non-stop at night and has even had small specks of blood in his sputum. The patient is otherwise healthy and recently moved to the United States from the Philippines. Temperature is 38.3 °C (101°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 123/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam reveals a malnourished patient and is notable for faint rales over the right lower lung field. Which of the following radiographic features is most indicative of this patient’s primary infectious process?

choices.text: Hilar lymphadenopathy and a primary focus of infection in the mid-lower lobes
Fibrocaseous cavitary lesion in the upper lobes

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient who recently immigrated from the Philippines presents with night sweats, fevers, and cough. Physical exam is notable for a cachexia, malnourishment, and diminished breath sounds over the right lower lung. Together, the history and exam findings are most concerning for primary pulmonary tuberculosis, of which the most common radiographic feature is hilar lymphadenopathy and a Ghon focus in the mid-lower lobes.    

Primary pulmonary tuberculosis describes a new tuberculosis infection or active disease in a previously naïve host. In primary disease, mycobacteria take up residence in lung tissue, typically the right lung in the mid/lower lobes due to a higher density of lymph nodes and anatomic preference given the longer length and smaller internal caliber of the right bronchus. Mycobacteria then form a primary focus of granulomatous infection, referred to as a Ghon focus, which along with hilar lymphadenopathy is referred to as a Ghon complex.     

The majority of patients with primary tuberculosis are asymptomatic. However, as the infection establishes, symptoms including fever, weight loss, anorexia, chills, cough, and night sweats may occur. Of these symptoms, fever, cough, and dyspnea are the most common. In the chronically ill or immunosuppressed patients, primary tuberculosis can lead to progressive primary tuberculosis, wherein the disease becomes widespread, and the bacteria seeds multiple organ systems. However, the vast majority of patients with primary tuberculosis have either spontaneous resolution of infection or progress to latent infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hilar lymphadenopathy and a primary focus of infection in the mid-lower lobes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fibrocaseous cavitary lesion in the upper lobes:
Incorrect: An upper lobe lesion is more indicative of secondary or reactivation tuberculosis. Patients with secondary tuberculosis typically have a history of untreated tuberculosis with recrudescent symptoms. 
❌ Cavitary caseating lesion :
Incorrect: Cavitary necrotic tuberculous lesions are more commonly seen in secondary tuberculosis. 
❌ Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates:
Incorrect: Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates can be seen radiographically in the setting of primary pulmonary tuberculosis infections. However, it is not the most common radiographic finding associated with primary tuberculosis. 
❌ Unilateral pleural effusion:
Incorrect: Pleural effusions are commonly seen in primary tuberculosis (approximately one third of cases). However, it is not the most common radiographic finding associated with primary tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of dyspnea for the past 2 days and is determined to have a COPD exacerbation. She has a 25-pack-year smoking history. Despite appropriate medical management, endotracheal intubation is required in the emergency department. On the fifth day of hospitalization, the patient develops a fever and increasingly purulent oral secretions. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 111/65 mmHg. A chest radiograph reveals new right middle lobe infiltrates. Sputum microscopy is notable for Gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient developed fevers, productive cough, and lung infiltrates several days after undergoing endotracheal intubation. These findings are concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia, which is a subtype of hospital-acquired pneumonia.  

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is diagnosed when a patient develops pneumonia 48 hours or more after being hospitalized for another condition. HAP tends to be more serious because these patients often have weakened immune systems, and the microbes in hospitals are often resistant to common antibiotics. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), which is commonly found in hospitals, and Legionellia pneumophila, which can be found in water systems, are common causes of HAP.  

A subtype of HAP is ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP describes pneumonia that develops after a patient has been intubated for more than 48 hours. Often, the condition is caused by bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a Gram-negative bacillus, and Staphylococcus aureus. These organisms can form biofilms on the endotracheal tube and are subsequently able to move from the tube directly into the lungs, resulting in pneumonia.  



Option Analysis

❌ Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect: Haemophilus influenzae is a Gram-negative coccobacillus that can cause community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient’s current pneumonia developed several days following endotracheal intubation, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP is commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus. 
❌ Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive coccus that can cause secondary bacterial pneumonia following an initial viral respiratory illness, as well as ventilator-associated pneumonia. However, this patient’s sputum culture demonstrated growth of a Gram-negative organism. 
❌ Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive cocci that can cause secondary bacterial pneumonia following an initial viral respiratory illness, as well as ventilator-associated pneumonia. However, this patient’s sputum culture demonstrated growth of a Gram-negative organism.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive cocci and is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient’s current pneumonia developed following endotracheal intubation, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP is often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus. 
✅ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man goes to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and dry cough for the past week. He has also become progressively more dyspneic, and walking a single block makes him short of breath. He underwent a liver transplantation 4-months ago for treatment of autoimmune hepatitis and is currently taking several immunosuppressant drugs. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 122/88 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral crackles and rhonchi. Chest radiograph reveals bilateral, diffuse interstitial infiltrates extending from the perihilar region. Leukocyte count is 13,000/mm3 and serum lactate dehydrogenase level is 460 U/L. Further testing is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Detection of bacterial antigen in urine
Presence of organisms in sputum that stain positive for methenamine silver
Growth of bacteria on cholesterol-rich agar
Identification of Gram-positive diplococci on sputum analysis
Visualization of acid-fast organisms on sputum microscopy

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, cough, and dyspnea in the setting of an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level and immunosuppression. He likely has pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii, which can be stained with silver methenamine.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (which goes by the abbreviation PCP based on its former genus-species name Pneumocystis carinii) is an opportunistic fungal lung infection occurring almost exclusively in immunocompromised individuals. On board examinations, PCP is classically seen in patients with untreated HIV. However, other populations at risk include transplant recipients as well as patients on chronic glucocorticoids or other immunosuppressive therapy.  

Patients with PCP typically have a gradual onset (days to weeks) of symptoms. When symptomatic, patients present with low-grade fever, nonproductive cough, malaise, and dyspnea. Lung auscultation can reveal bilateral crackles and rhonchi.    

Laboratory testing can demonstrate elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels secondary to lung injury and inflammation caused by P. jirovecii. Chest radiography will classically show bilateral, diffuse interstitial infiltrates (see below). Finally, methenamine silver staining allows for visualization of disc-shaped P. jirovecii cysts, which is necessary to make a definitive diagnosis.  



Image reproduced from Radiopaedia

Option Analysis

❌ Detection of bacterial antigen in urine:
Incorrect: Legionella pneumophila and Streptococcus pneumoniae infection can be diagnosed using urinary antigen testing. However, this patient’s elevated lactate dehydrogenase level and history of immunosuppression are more concerning for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. 
✅ Presence of organisms in sputum that stain positive for methenamine silver:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Growth of bacteria on cholesterol-rich agar:
Incorrect:Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common bacterial cause of community-acquired pneumonia in young adults and is transmitted from person to person primarily via respiratory droplets. The pathogen can grow on a type of cholesterol-rich agar known as Eaton agar. However, this patient is taking multiple immunosuppressants and has an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level, which are more concerning for infection by a different pathogen.
❌ Identification of Gram-positive diplococci on sputum analysis  :
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive diplococci and is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. However, pneumococcal pneumonia typically presents with more rapid onset and often causes lobar consolidation, as opposed to diffuse, bilateral interstitial infiltrates.
❌ Visualization of acid-fast organisms on sputum microscopy:
Incorrect: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an acid-fast organism that can cause respiratory infection. Since Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an aerobic organism, it preferentially colonizes the upper lobes of the lungs, where oxygen concentration is highest. Patients can present with hemoptysis, night sweats, and weight loss.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of a sore throat and fever. The patient’s parent states, “She has been having a sore throat for three days now, and she’s also had some difficulty eating.” Past medical history is unremarkable, and she is up to date on all vaccinations. Physical examination demonstrates bilateral tonsillar swelling with exudate and submandibular lymphadenopathy. Additional physical examination findings are demonstrated below.


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following substances synthesized by the causative pathogen is most likely responsible for this patient’s dermatologic findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has findings consistent with scarlet fever, including a diffuse scarlatiniform rash, strawberry tongue, and exudative pharyngitis. The condition is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. The virulence factor responsible for the dermatologic findings is streptococcal erythrogenic exotoxin.

Scarlet fever refers to a constellation of symptoms due Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis that includes sore throat, fever, lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse erythematous rash. The rash is a consequence of streptococcal erythrogenic exotoxin, which acts as a superantigen that induces inflammation by nonspecifically activating T-cells and stimulating inflammatory cytokine production.

The rash is frequently described as small, red papules that give the skin a “sand-paper like” texture. The rash typically begins at the skin folds and spreads to involve most of the body’s surface area. After approximately one week, the rash begins to desquamate (shedding of the outer layer of skin). In addition, this rash can manifest on the tongue, giving a characteristic strawberry appearance.

Option Analysis

✅ Erythrogenic exotoxin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cord factor:
Incorrect: Cord factor is a pathogenic factor associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis and aids in granuloma formation. However, it is not associated with Streptococcus pyogenes or the pathogenesis of scarlet fever.
❌ Toxin B:
Incorrect: Toxin B is produced by Clostridium difficile and results in destabilization of the actin cytoskeleton. The pathogen can result in abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. However, Clostridium difficile is not involved in the pathogenesis of scarlet fever.
❌ IgA protease:
Incorrect: IgA protease is a virulence factor synthesized by organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, as well as Neisseria gonorrhoeae. IgA protease allows these pathogens to adhere to and proliferate on mucous membranes. In contrast, IgA protease is not implicated in the pathogenesis of scarlet fever.
❌ Streptolysin O:
Incorrect: Streptolysin O is a virulence factor produced by Streptococcus pyogenes. It can cause beta-hemolysis and cell membrane degeneration. However, it is not involved in the pathogenesis of scarlet fever.

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department in winter for evaluation of increased work of breathing. According to his parents, the patient developed a runny nose and congestion earlier in the week. However, over the past day, he also began experiencing cough, fever, and shortness of breath. The patient is otherwise healthy, was born full-term, and is up-to-date on all vaccinations. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 90/52 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have nasal flaring, subcostal retractions, and bilateral end-expiratory wheezing. Bedside nasal suctioning is performed and leads to symptomatic improvement. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with congestion progressing to cough, wheezing, and increased work of breathing. In the pediatric population, particularly infants less than 2-years-old, these symptoms are most consistent with viral bronchiolitis. It is most often caused by the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

Bronchiolitis is a respiratory illness usually affecting children aged less than 2-years-old. It is characterized by upper airway disease (e.g., cough, runny nose) followed by lower airway involvement (e.g., wheezing, rales) several days later. The most common precipitant is respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), which belongs to the family of paramyxoviridae. Less common causes include the parainfluenza virus, influenza virus, and adenovirus. The disease is usually observed in the winter or fall given the virus’s enhanced ability to survive in colder, drier conditions.

Bronchiolitis is diagnosed clinically, and treatment is primarily supportive via administration of antipyretics, fluids, and suctioning of secretions. However, infants with cardiopulmonary comorbidities, immunosuppression, or preterm birth are at risk for severe disease requiring non-invasive ventilation or mechanical ventilation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Respiratory syncytial virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Parainfluenza virus 1:
Incorrect: Parainfluenza virus types 1 and 2 are the most common cause of croup. These viruses are occasionally implicated in the development of bronchiolitis, which manifests with wheezing and increased respiratory effort. However, the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the most common cause of bronchiolitis.
❌ Adenovirus:
Incorrect: This patient presents with wheezing and increased respiratory effort, which are concerning for bronchiolitis. The condition is most commonly caused by the respiratory syncytial virus. In contrast, adenovirus is more often associated with pharyngitis, pneumonia, and hemorrhagic cystitis.
❌ Rhinovirus:
Incorrect: Rhinoviruses are the most common cause of the common cold, which can manifest with cough, nasal congestion, sore throat, and malaise. Although this patient has some cold-like symptoms, he also has bilateral wheezing and increased work of breathing, which are suggestive of bronchiolitis. Rhinoviruses are not the most common cause of bronchiolitis.
❌ Orthomyxovirus:
Incorrect: Orthomyxoviruses can cause influenza-like illness, which is characterized by fever, myalgia, rigors, and fatigue. In contrast, orthomyxoviruses are an uncommon cause of bronchiolitis.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old female with a history of Crohn disease is admitted to the hospital with worsening cough, fevers, and night sweats. She is a medical student and recently returned from a mission trip to Honduras. She is otherwise healthy, does not smoke or use illicit drugs, and takes infliximab for management of the inflammatory bowel disease. She subsequently undergoes a lung biopsy, which demonstrates the following microscopic finding:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following cell types is responsible for the development of the observed microscopic lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is currently taking an immunosuppressive agent (infliximab), presents with worsening cough, fevers, and night sweats after returning from a medical mission trip to Honduras. The above microscopic slide demonstrates caseous necrosis, which is consistent with primary pulmonary tuberculosis.

The development of caseous necrosis is mediated by the chemical and immunological responses of both macrophages and T-helper 1 cells. Approximately 3 weeks after infection, tubercular cord factor triggers a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, wherein macrophages housing mycobacteria in phagosomes travel through the pulmonary lymphatics and present mycobacterial antigens to naive CD4 T-helper cells.    

The macrophages also secrete IL-12, which differentiates the CD4 cells into T-helper 1 cells. The T-helper 1 cells then migrate to the site of infection, where they release interferon-gamma and activate additional macrophages. As more macrophages become activated, they recruit even more macrophages and neutrophils via release of TNF-alpha. These cells surround the bacteria and form epithelioid histiocytes, multinucleated Langhans giant cells, and granulomas. Over time, the center of granuloma becomes laden with cellular debris, resulting in the appearance of caseous necrosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ T-helper subtype 1  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eosinophils :
Incorrect: Eosinophils are responsible for fighting parasitic infections, as well as mediating the mechanisms associated with allergies and asthma. Eosinophils are not involved in granuloma formation.   
❌ T-helper subtype 2 :
Incorrect: Th2 cells activate eosinophils and promote IgE production for defense against parasitic infections. Th2 cells are induced by interferon-gamma secreted by Th1 cells. However, Th2 cells do not play a role in granuloma formation.   
❌ B-lymphocytes:
Incorrect: B-lymphocytes are responsible for the development of humoral immunity and antibody production. They are not involved in the formation of caseous granulomas in mycobacterial infection. 
❌ Natural killer cells:
Incorrect: Natural killer cells are members of the innate immune system. They are responsible for triggering apoptosis and death of virally infected cells and tumor cells. However, natural killer cells are not involved in granuloma formation.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man with a past medical history of COPD and hypertension is brought to the emergency department because of dyspnea over the past 2 days. He has a 25-pack year smoking history. On arrival, the patient has altered mental status and impending respiratory failure. Endotracheal intubation is performed in the emergency department. A chest radiograph demonstrates lung hyperinflation but no consolidation or infiltrates. The patient is started on bronchodilators, antibiotics, and corticosteroid therapy. On the fifth day of hospitalization, while still intubated, the patient develops a fever as well as yellowish, purulent secretions. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 151/85 mmHg. Repeat chest radiograph reveals new right middle lobe infiltrates. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has fevers, productive cough, and lung infiltrates several days after undergoing endotracheal intubation. He most likely has ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is a type of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) that develops after a patient has been intubated for more than 48 hours.  

Common causes of VAP include bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. These organisms can form biofilms within the endotracheal tube. Individuals on ventilators are unable to cough, and over time, bacteria are able to move from the tube directly into the lungs. Risk factors for developing VAP include older age, prolonged intubation, chronic lung disease (e.g. COPD), depressed mental status, and aspiration.  

Clinically, VAP can manifest with fever, purulent secretions, increased respiratory rate, and decreased oxygen saturation. Chest imaging may demonstrate the presence of new pulmonary infiltrates, and laboratory testing may demonstrate leukocytosis.  

Recommended practices for preventing VAP include avoiding intubation when possible, minimizing sedation, minimizing pooling of secretions above the endotracheal tube cuff, and elevating the head of the bed.  



Option Analysis

❌ Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect: Haemophilus influenzae is a Gram-negative coccobacilli that can cause community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient’s current pneumonia developed several days following endotracheal intubation, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP is often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus. 
❌ Legionellia pneumophila:
Incorrect:Legionellia pneumophila can be found in water systems (e.g. water-based cooling systems) and may cause pneumonia. However, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a more common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia and can account for around 25% of cases in some studies.
❌ Mycoplasma pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient developed pneumonia after being intubated for several days, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Mycoplasma pneumoniae is not a well-documented cause of VAP.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive coccus and one of the most common causes of community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient’s current pneumonia developed following endotracheal intubation, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP is commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus. 
✅ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of sinus pressure. The patient has had a stuffy nose with purulent nasal discharge for the past two weeks. In addition, he has been experiencing headaches and ear fullness. His symptoms began improving around 11-12 days after onset but then took a turn for the worse. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin daily. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/71 mmHg. Physical exam demonstrates tenderness to palpation over the bilateral maxillary sinuses. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of rhinosinusitis including nasal discharge, ear fullness, headache, and sinus tenderness. Given the patient’s prolonged course of illness, biphasic pattern, and presence of purulent discharge, his presentation is most consistent with bacterial rhinosinusitis. The condition is often caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Rhinosinusitis is characterized by inflammation and obstruction of sinus drainage through the nasal cavities. Viral pathogens, such as rhinovirus, influenza virus, and parainfluenza viruses, are the most common cause. Bacterial causes of rhinosinusitis include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophiluus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.

As these pathogens infect the nasal mucosa, inflammation follows, causing hypersecretion and increased vascular permeability. These changes result in extravasation of fluids into the nasal cavity and sinuses. Furthermore, many of these pathogens exert direct toxic effect on nasal cilia, impairing mucociliary clearance. Ultimately, this combination of mucosal edema, thickened secretions, and impaired mucociliary clearance results in sinus obstruction.

Rhinosinusitis can manifest with nasal discharge, sinus fullness or pressure, headache, fever, ear pressure, and loss of smell. In viral rhinosinusitis, symptoms typically resolve in 7-10 days. In contrast, bacterial rhinosinusitis often persists beyond ten days, and patients can experience a biphasic illness pattern, which is characterized by initial symptomatic improvement followed by subsequent exacerbation. If untreated, bacterial rhinosinusitis can lead to infection of the deeper facial structures, potentially causing orbital cellulitis, meningitis, or cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: Findings associated with Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis include fever, tonsillar swelling with exudates, and tender lymphadenopathy. If left untreated, patients may develop complications such as rheumatic fever and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. However, S. pyogenes is not a common cause of rhinosinusitis.
❌ Moraxella catarrhalis :
Incorrect: Moraxella catarrhalis is a well established etiology of bacterial sinusitis. However, it is overall a less common cause than Streptococcus pneumoniae.
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: This patient presents with purulent nasal discharge, headaches, ear fullness, and sinus tenderness. These symptoms are concerning for bacterial rhinosinusitis. Staphylococcus aureus is not a well established cause of bacterial rhinosinusitis. Instead, the pathogen is more commonly implicated in skin and soft tissue infections, septic arthritis, and osteomyelitis.
❌ Enterococcus faecalis:
Incorrect: Enterococcus faecalis is part of the normal colonic flora. It can give rise to urinary tract infections, biliary tract infections, and subacute endocarditis. However, it is not a well-documented cause of bacterial rhinosinusitis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with increased work of breathing. His parents, who are at the bedside, recall that the patient developed a “stuffy nose” two days ago. This morning, he was noted to have a hoarse voice, drooling, and increased work of breathing. The patient was born full-term at home and has rarely seen a physician. Past medical history is otherwise noncontributory. Temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is noted to be leaning forward with the neck hyperextended and chin thrust forward. The patient is drooling and has stridorous breathing. Radiographic imaging reveals the following finding:



Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following best describes the medication that would have been most effective in preventing this patient’s current symptoms?

choices.text: Type b capsular polysaccharide conjugated to diphtheria toxoid
Monoclonal antibody that binds RSV envelope fusion protein
Purified polysaccharides from Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci

questions.solution:
This patient presents with dysphagia, drooling, respiratory distress, and neck imaging demonstrating a swollen epiglottis. He likely has epiglottitis. This condition has become increasingly rare due to widespread administration of the Hib subunit vaccine, which consists of the type b capsular polysaccharide conjugated to diphtheria toxoid. However, unvaccinated children are still at risk for developing the condition.

The most common infectious organism associated with pediatric epiglottitis is Haemophilus influenzae (specifically type B). In contrast, the underlying etiology of adult epiglottitis is more varied. Infection by H. influenzae results in cellulitis of the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and adjacent tissue, which rapidly progresses to edema and narrowing of the airway.

The condition can manifest with fever, stridor, dysphagia, respiratory distress, and significant anxiety. Classically, patients will also lean their trunk forward and hyperextend the neck with chin protrusion to maximize airway opening. The posture is termed the “sniffing position” or “tripod position.” Lateral neck radiographs will often demonstrate the thumbprint sign due to an edematous glottis.

If untreated, epiglottitis can rapidly progress to loss of the airway and hypoxemic arrest. Patients should be judiciously evaluated for impending airway collapse, and endotracheal intubation may be necessary. Furthermore, if untreated, epiglottitis can progress to epiglottic abscess and bacteremia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Type b capsular polysaccharide conjugated to diphtheria toxoid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of peptidoglycan cross-linking:
Incorrect: This patient has dysphagia, drooling, respiratory distress, and a swollen epiglottis on neck imaging. He likely has epiglottitis. Cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone and cefotaxime, can be used to treat epiglottitis. However, these medications are not used for prophylaxis.
❌ Monoclonal antibody that binds RSV envelope fusion protein:
Incorrect: Palvizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds RSV envelope fusion protein (RSV F), thereby preventing the virus from fusing with host cells. The medication can be administered to premature and high risk infants for RSV prophylaxis. However, Palivizumab would be ineffective in preventing the Haemophilus influenzae infection that likely precipitated this patient’s epiglottitis.
❌ Inactivated orthomyxovirus:
Incorrect: The yearly influenza vaccine involves administration of a live-attenuated version of the influenza virus, which is a type of orthomyxovirus. The vaccine allows the recipient to develop antibodies against viral neuraminidase and hemagglutinin receptors, thereby helping confer immunity. However, the influenza virus does not lead to epiglottitis.
❌ Purified polysaccharides from Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci:
Incorrect: The pneumococcal vaccine protects against infection by the Gram-positive, lancet-shaped bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae. Although Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause epiglottitis, Haemophilus influenzae is overall a more common cause in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and cough that have been going on for the past four days. The cough is productive and yields purulent, foul-smelling sputum. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 121/65 mmHg. The patient’s pulse oximetry shows 91% on room air. Crackles are heard bilaterally. Chest radiograph reveals infiltrations in the basilar region of both lungs. Sputum Gram-stain is notable for neutrophils and Gram-negative organisms. Subsequent sputum culture yields growth of Klebsiella and Bacteroides species. Which of the following is most likely to be found upon further interviewing this patient?

choices.text: Exposure to contaminated water-based cooling systems

questions.solution:
This patient has fevers, consolidations primarily affecting the basilar lungs, and sputum culture yielding growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria. These findings suggest aspiration pneumonia.

Aspiration pneumonia occurs when patients accidentally aspirate food, drinks, or gastric contents. The condition typically occurs in patients with impaired gag and cough reflexes or altered consciousness. Therefore, aspiration pneumonia is more common in patients with a history of drug or alcohol intoxication, seizure disorders, or stroke leading to swallowing issues.  

The right lung is preferentially involved due to the larger caliber and vertical orientation of the right mainstem bronchus. Furthermore, aspiration pneumonia is gravity-dependent, meaning the location where pneumonia develops depends on the patient’s position. In patients who aspirate while lying on their back, pneumonia will likely develop in the posterior segment of the upper lobe and superior segment of the lower lobe. In patients who aspirate while upright, the basilar segments may be affected.

Since aspiration pneumonia is caused by a mixture of aspirated gastric contents and oral secretions, sputum Gram-stain will typically reveal mixed infections with aerobic and anaerobic organisms. Clinically, patients may have crackles on auscultation, high fevers, shortness of breath, and a productive cough with foul-smelling sputum. 



Option Analysis

❌ Close quarters living arrangement:
Incorrect: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) in children and young adults. The organism is transmitted from person to person primarily via respiratory droplets. Therefore, outbreaks most frequently occur among persons living in close quarters (e.g., dormitories, military facilities). However, this patient’s sputum culture yields growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic organisms, which is more concerning for aspiration pneumonia.
❌ Exposure to contaminated water-based cooling systems:
Incorrect: Legionella pneumophila (legionellosis) can be found in contaminated water sources and is a cause of atypical pneumonia, which would similarly present with fevers and cough. However, patients with legionellosis also often have extrapulmonary symptoms, such as diarrhea, nausea/vomiting, and confusion. Additionally, this patient’s sputum cultures yield growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic organisms, which is more concerning for aspiration pneumonia.
❌ History of incarceration:
Incorrect: A history of incarceration is a risk factor for tuberculosis infection. In contrast, this patient has bilateral basilar infiltrates and cultures that yield growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic organisms, which is more concerning for aspiration pneumonia.
❌ Recent history of spelunking:
Incorrect: Spelunking can place an individual at risk for histoplasmosis, which is caused by the pathogen Histoplasma capsulatum. In contrast, this patient’s culture yields growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic organisms, which is more concerning for aspiration pneumonia.
✅ History of alcohol intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, cough, and night sweats over the past 2-3 months. Past medical history is notable for HIV infection, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. She is currently undomiciled, drinks 3-4 alcoholic drinks per day, smokes one pack of cigarettes per day, and uses intravenous heroin daily. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99.0°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 156/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates a thin, cachectic middle aged female with track marks noted on the upper extremities bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals rales in the upper lobe of the left lung, without gallops, rubs, or murmurs. Chest x-ray is demonstrated below.  

 

Image reproduced from Radiopaedia  
Which of the following is the most important contributing factor for the development of this radiographic finding?

choices.text: Higher oxygen tension in upper lung lobes

questions.solution:
This patient has clinical features (e.g., chronic cough, night sweats) and a social history (e.g., undomiciled status, polysubstance use) suspicious for Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. The chest x-ray demonstrates an infiltrate in the upper lobe of the left lung, which is consistent with reactivation or secondary tuberculosis.   

Unlike primary pulmonary tuberculosis, reactivation or secondary tuberculosis tends to affect the upper lobes of the lung. This phenomenon is due to the fact that mycobacteria are obligate aerobes, and the upper lobes have a higher oxygen tension and poor lymphatic drainage, which allows the bacteria to replicate more effectively.  

Reactivation tuberculosis refers to recrudescent infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis after a period of dormancy. Typically, primary disease occurs when aerosolized tuberculi take residence in lung tissue, typically the mid/lower lobes of the right lung due to a higher density of lymph nodes and anatomic preference. Mycobacteria then form a primary focus of granulomatous infection, referred to as a Ghon focus, which, along with hilar lymphadenopathy, is referred to as a Ghon complex. If the Ghon focus or complex fails to be cleared by the immune system, mycobacteria can travel to the upper lobes of the lung and form new foci, resulting in fibrocaseous cavitary lesions and secondary tuberculosis. If left untreated, further localized destruction, bacteremia, and disseminated disease may ensue.    

Option Analysis

✅ Higher oxygen tension in upper lung lobes:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Impaired phagolysosome formation by macrophages:
Incorrect: Mycobacterium tuberculosis uses sulfatide to prevent phagolysosome formation while inside of macrophages. However, this is not the most important factor contributing to the formation of reactivation tuberculosis in the upper lobes of the lung.   
❌ Inhibition of opsonization:
Incorrect: The primary virulence factor of Streptococcus pneumoniae is a polysaccharide capsule that prevents opsonization and phagocytosis. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with reactivation tuberculosis, making this answer choice unlikely. 
❌ Embolization of bacterial vegetations:
